1	de	of, from, some, any	det, prep	[də, dy, de]					1. de From Latin dē.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
2	je	I	pro	[ʒə, ʒ]					2. je From Old French jo, from Vulgar Latin *eo, from Latin ego, from Proto-Indo-European *éǵh₂. Near cognates include Spanish yo and Italian io. Further cognates include Ancient Greek ἐγώ (egṓ), Russian я (ya), English I, German ich, etc.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
3	pas	not, no	adv,nm(pl)	[pɑ]					3. pas From Latin passus. Its use as an auxiliary adverb comes from an accusative use (Latin nec... passum) in negative constructions – literally ‘not... a step’, i.e. ‘not at all’ – originally used with certain verbs of motion.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
4	le	the; him, her, it, them	det, pro	[lə]					4. le From Old French le, from Latin illum, by dropping il- and -m. Latin illum is the accusative singular of ille.[1]	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
5	que	that, which, who, whom	adv,conj,pro	[kə]					5. que 1 From Latin quia. From Latin quam. From Latin quid, from Proto-Indo-European *kʷid, compare *kʷis. From Latin quem, accusative of qui.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
6	tu	you	pro	[ty]					6. tu 1 From Old French tu, from Latin tū, from Proto-Italic *tū, from Proto-Indo-European *túh₂.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
7	vous	you(pl)	pro	[vu]					7. vous From Middle French vous, from Old French vos, vous, from Latin vōs, from Proto-Italic *wōs.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
8	un	a, an, one	adj, det, nm, pro	[œ͂]					8. un From Old French un, from Latin ūnum, accusative singular of ūnus (“one”), from Old Latin oinos, from Proto-Italic *oinos, from Proto-Indo-European *óynos.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
9	et	and	conj	[e]					9. et From Latin et (“and; plus”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
10	à	to, at, in	prep	[a]					10. à From Old French a, from Latin ad, from Proto-Indo-European *ád (“near; at”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
11	il	he, it	pro	[il]					11. il From Middle French il, from Old French il, from Vulgar Latin *illī, which is derived from Classical Latin ille.[1]	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
12	ne	not	adv	[nə]					12. ne From Latin nōn.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
13	en	in, by	adv,prep,pro	[ɑ͂]					13. en 1 From Middle French en, from Old French en, from Latin in, from Proto-Italic *en, from Proto-Indo-European *h₁én (“in”). From Latin inde (“thence”). Compare Catalan en.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
14	on	one, we	pro	[ɔ͂]					14. on From Old French hom, om (nominative form), from the homō (“human being”) (compare homme from the Old French oblique form home, from the Latin accusative form hominem). Its pronominal use is of Germanic origin. Compare Old English man (“one, they, people”), reduced form of Old English mann (“man, person”); Catalan hom; German man (“one, they, people”); Dutch men (“one, they, people”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
15	ce	this, that	det,pro	[sə]					15. ce 1 From Old French cel, from earlier cil, from Vulgar Latin *ecce illu, from Latin ecce or eccum illum, from ille. Probably from Latin ecce hoc.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
16	pour	for, in order to	prep	[puʀ]					16. pour From Old French por, from Latin pro.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
17	qui	who, whom	pro	[ki]					17. qui From Middle French qui, from Old French qui, from Latin quī, from Old Latin quei, from Proto-Italic *kʷoi, from Proto-Indo-European *kʷos, *kʷis.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
18	mais	but	adv,conj,intj	[mɛ]					18. mais From Old French mes, mais, from Latin magis.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
19	dans	in, into, from	prep	[dɑ͂]					19. dans 1 From Vulgar Latin de intus or deintus, meaning 'from inside' or 'from within'. See dan.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
20	nous	we, us	pro	[nu]					20. nous 1 From Middle French nous, from Old French nous, nos, from Latin nōs, from Proto-Italic *nōs. From Ancient Greek νοῦς (noûs) or νόος (nóos, “mind”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
21	elle	she, her	pro	[ɛl]					21. elle 1 From Old French ele, from Latin illa, feminine of ille.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
22	bien	well	adji,adv,nm	[bjɛ͂]					22. bien From Middle French bien, from Old French bien, from Latin bene (“well”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
24	me	me, to me, myself	pro	[mə]					24. me From Middle French me, from Old French me, from Latin mē (accusative of ego), from Proto-Indo-European *(e)me-, *(e)me-n- (“me”). Northern dialects have preserved a form mi for the indirect object (also found in Old French in the Oaths of Strasbourg), from Latin mihi, dative singular of ego, through a Vulgar Latin *mi, whereas in standard French, it has merged into me.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
25	si	if, whether	adv,conj,nmi	[si]					25. si 1 From Old French se, from Latin si (“if”). From Old French si, from Latin sic (“so, thus”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
26	y	there	adv,nmi,pro	[igʀɛk]					26. y 1 From i grec (“Greek i”), referring to the letter upsilon (Υ), originally borrowed from the Greek alphabet, as opposed to 'Latin i' (I). 10th century; from Old French i, from Latin hīc (“here”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *ǵʰi-ḱe (“this, here”)), with meaning influenced by Old French iv (“there, thither”), itself from Latin ibī. Derivation from the latter poses difficulty from a phonetic standpoint. Eye dialect spelling of il. or Contraction of il. .	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
27	non	no, not	adv,nmi	[nɔ͂]					27. non From Old French non, from Latin nōn.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
28	avec	with	prep	[avɛk]					28. avec From Middle French avec, avecques (“with”), from Old French avoc, avoec, avuec (“with”), from an assumed Vulgar Latin *aboc, *abhoc, *apud hŏque[1][2], a Frankish alteration consisting of Latin apud (“with, near, close to”) with hoc (“this”) and -que. First used as a replacement for Latin cum (“with”) in Merovingian and Carolingian (Frankish) documents. Gradually supplanted Old French od (“with”), itself from apud.[2] Cognate with Picard aveuc, Norman aveu, Walloon avou and Franco-Provençal: avouéc.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
29	tout	all, very	adv,det,nadj,pro	[tu]					29. tout From Middle French tout, from Old French tot, from Latin tōtus; compare Catalan tot, Italian tutto, Portuguese todo, Romanian tot, Spanish todo.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
30	plus	more, no more	adv	[ply]					30. plus 1 From Old French plus, from Latin plus, from Old Latin *plous, from Proto-Indo-European *pleh₁-, *pelh₁u- (“many”). Inflected forms.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
31	mon	my	det	[mɔ͂, me]					31. mon From Middle French mon, from Old French mun, from Vulgar Latin, Late Latin mum, a reduced variant of Latin meum, nominative neuter singular of meus.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
32	te	you, to you, from you	pro	[tə]					32. te From Middle French te, from Old French te, from Latin tē, (accusative of tū), from Proto-Indo-European *twé, *te, accusative of *túh₂ (“you”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
33	fait	done, fact	adj,nm	[fɛ]					33. fait From Middle French fait, from Old French fet, from Latin factum.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
34	moi	me	nm,pro	[mwa]					34. moi From Middle French moy, from Old French mei, moi, mi (“me”), tonic form of me, from Latin mē (“me”), from Proto-Indo-European *(e)me-, *(e)me-n- (“me”). More at me.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
35	oui	yes	adv,nmi	[ˊwi]					35. oui [1380]; from Old French oïl (1100), compound of o affirmative particle (compare Occitan òc ‘yes’) and il ‘he, him’, akin to o-je, o-tu, o nos, o vos, all ‘yes’ constructed with pronouns.[1] O and òc are both from Latin hoc ‘this’. Compare Portuguese isso ‘yes, yeah’, literally ‘this, that’. And the semantic shift is calqued on Gaulish: Compare fellow Celtic languages such as Old Irish tó ‘yes’, Welsh do ‘indeed’, from Proto-Indo-European *tod (“this, that”).[2]	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
36	faire	to do, make	nm,v	[fɛʀ]					36. faire From Middle French faire, from Old French faire, feire, fere, from Latin facere, present active infinitive of faciō, from Proto-Italic *fakiō, from Proto-Indo-European *dʰeh₁- (“to put, place, set”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
37	sur	on, upon	adj,prep	[syʀ]					37. sur 1 From Middle French sur, from Old French sur, seur, sor, soure, souvre, sovre (“on, upon, over”), from Latin super (“over, on, above”), from *eks-uper, from *h₁eǵʰs (“out of”) (Latin ex) and *uperi (“above”), from *upo. Doublet of super, a borrowing. Cognate with Old English ofer (“over, above”). More at over. From Middle French sur, from Old French sur (“sour, bitter”), from Frankish *sūr (“acidic, sour”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
38	quoi	what	pro	[kwa]					38. quoi From Latin quid; ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *kʷid, compare *kʷis. Cognate to English what, which differs due to changing under Grimm’s law.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
39	se	oneself, himself, herself, itself, themselves	pro	[sə]					39. se From Middle French se, from Old French se, from Latin sē, from Proto-Indo-European *swé (reflexive pronoun). See also soi.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
40	comme	like, as	adv,conj	[kɔm]					40. comme From Middle French comme, from Old French cum, com, conme, from Vulgar Latin *quomo, from Latin quōmodo.[1] Later the conjunction et was added to com, resulting in comme.[2] Cognate to Italian come. See also Spanish como and Catalan com.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
41	être	to be; being	nm,v	[ɛtʀ]					41. être From Middle French estre, from a merger of two verbs:	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
42	ici	here	adv	[isi]		• Je suis ici. I am here. • Qui était ici? Who was here ?	Je suis ici. Qui était ici?		42. ici From an i taken from an Old French iluec (from Latin illoc) + ci, itself from Latin ecce hīc.	[1]	[2]	[3]
43	toi	you, yourself	nm,pro	[twa]		• Je suis avec toi. I'm by your side. • Bien fait pour toi. That serves you right.	Je suis avec toi. Bien fait pour toi.		43. toi From Middle French toi, tei, from Old French tei, te, from Latin tē.	[1]	[2]	[3]
44	dit	said, so-called; tale	nadj	[di, dit]					44. dit From Old French dit, from Latin dictus.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
45	lui	him, her	pro	[lɥi]		• Elle est tout pour lui. She is everything to him. • Je lui ai dit quoi faire. I told him what to do.	Elle est tout pour lui. Je lui ai dit quoi faire.		45. lui 1 From Vulgar Latin *illūi, which is a Vulgar Latin form of Latin illī (dative singular of ille). The -ui ending in Vulgar Latin illui is due to the influence of cui.[1] see the verb luire	[1]	[2]	[3]
46	votre	your	det	[vɔtʀ]					46. votre From Middle French vostre, from Old French vostre, from Latin voster, vostrum, vostra(m), from earlier vester, from Proto-Italic *westeros.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
47	pourquoi	why	adv,conj,nmi	[puʀkwa]					47. pourquoi From Middle French parquoy, from Old French por quoi.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
48	où	where	adv,pro	[u]		• Je sais où elle est. I know where she is.	Je sais où elle est.		48. où From Middle French où, from Old French ou, from Latin ubi (“where?”). The grave accent was added in Middle French to differentiate from ou (“or”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
49	rien	nothing	adv,nm,pro	[ʀjɛ͂]		• Je ne sais rien de lui. I don't know anything about him.	Je ne sais rien de lui.		49. rien From Old French rien, from Latin rem, accusative of rēs (“thing”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
50	là	there, here	adv,intj	[la]		• Il est là. There it is. • Qui va là? Who goes there ? • Tout est là. It's all there.	Il est là. Qui va là? Tout est là.		50. là From Middle French la, from Old French la, from Latin illac. The grave accent on the a was added to disambiguate with la (“the”). Compare Spanish allá, Portuguese lá.	[1]	[2]	[3]
51	quand	when	adv,conj	[kɑ͂]					51. quand From Middle French quand, quant, from Old French quant, qant, from Latin quandō.[1]	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
52	dire	to say	nm,v	[diʀ]		• Je veux vous le dire. I want to tell you. • Dites toujours la vérité. Always tell the truth. • Tous mes amis disent ça. All my friends say that.	Je veux vous le dire. Dites toujours la vérité. Tous mes amis disent ça.		52. dire From Middle French dire, from Old French dire, from Latin dīcere, present active infinitive of dīcō, from Proto-Italic *deikō, from Proto-Indo-European *déyḱti (“to show, point out”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
53	son	his, her, its; sound	det,nm	[sɔ͂]					53. son 1 From Old French son, suen, suon, from Latin sonus (the current form may be remade after or influenced by sonner). From Middle French son, from Old French son, from Vulgar Latin sum, a reduced/atonic variant of suus, suum, from Proto-Italic *sowos, from Proto-Indo-European *sewos, from *swé (“self”). From Latin secundus (presumably through an earlier Old French form *seon; cf. an attested Medieval Latin seonno, seonnum). Cognate with Catalan segó, Old Occitan segon. The meaning derives from the fact that bran results from a second sifting of flour. Doublet of second, a borrowing.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
54	ton	your	det,nm	[tɔ͂]					54. ton 1 From Old French ton, tos, from Latin tuus, from Proto-Indo-European *towos. Borrowed from Latin tonus. Doublet of tonus, a later borrowing.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
55	alors	then, so	adv	[alɔʀ]					55. alors From Old French a +‎ lors.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
56	comment	how	adv,conj,intj,nmi	[kɔmɑ͂]		• Comment ça va? How are you ?	Comment ça va?		56. comment comme +‎ -ment[1]	[1]	[2]	[3]
57	par	by	prep	[paʀ]					57. par From Middle French par, from Old French par, from Latin per, from Proto-Indo-European *peri.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
58	ou	or	conj	[u]					58. ou From Old French ou, from Latin aut.[1]	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
59	la chose	thing	adj(f),nf	[ʃoz]					59. chose From Old French chose, from Latin causa. Compare Italian cosa, Portuguese coisa, Spanish cosa among many others. Compare cause, a borrowed doublet.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
60	bon	good	adj,adv,intj,nm	[bɔ͂]		• Je suis bon. I am good. • Vous êtes vraiment bons. You really are good. • Nous sommes bons amis. We are good friends. • Vous êtes bons. You are good.	Je suis bon. Vous êtes vraiment bons. Nous sommes bons amis. Vous êtes bons.		60. bon From Middle French bon, from Old French bon, from Latin bonus (“good”), from Old Latin duenos, later duonus, from Proto-Italic *dwenos, from Proto-Indo-European *dew- (“to show favor, revere”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
61	le merci, la merci	thank you; favor	intj,nm,nf	[mɛʀsi]					61. merci From Middle French merci, mercy, from Old French merci, from Latin mercēdem, accusative singular of mercēs (“wages, fee, price”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
62	juste	just, only; fair	adv,nadj(f)	[ʒyst]					62. juste From Old French juste, in this form probably borrowed from Latin iūstus, jūstus, from Proto-Italic *jowestos, from Proto-Indo-European *h₂yew-. The Old French form just may have been inherited, however, and perhaps later modified based on the Latin.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
63	très	very	adv	[tʀɛ]		• Je vais très bien. I feel very good.	Je vais très bien.		63. très From Old French trés, inherited from Latin trans. Doublet of trans-.	[1]	[2]	[3]
64	jamais	never	adv	[ʒamɛ]					64. jamais From Old French ja més, jamés (“ever”), from Latin iam magis (“yet more”). Compare Spanish jamás, Italian giammai and Portuguese jamais.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
65	un été	"summer; past particle of être (""to be"")"	nm	[ete]					65. été 1 From Old French esté, from Latin aestās, aestātem, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *h₂eydʰ- (“burn; fire”). From Latin stātus, past participle of stō (which was conflated with sum in Old French). Compare also the noun état.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
66	avoir	to have	nm,v	[avwaʀ]					66. avoir From Middle French avoir, from Old French avoir, aveir, aver, from Vulgar Latin *avēre, from Latin habēre, present active infinitive of habeō (“have, hold, possess”), probably from a Proto-Italic *habēō or *haβēō, possibly ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *gʰh₁bʰ- (“to grab, to take”). Influenced and reinforced by similar (yet etymologically unrelated) verbs in Germanic; compare Frankish *habēn, *hebōn (“to have”), Gothic 𐌷𐌰𐌱𐌰𐌽 (haban, “to have”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
67	vraiment	truly, really, very	adv	[vʀɛmɑ͂]		• Tu es vraiment bon. You really are good.	Tu es vraiment bon.		67. vraiment From Middle French vrayement, from Old French veraiement, equivalent to vrai +‎ -ment. Compare Italian veramente.	[1]	[2]	[3]
68	aussi	too, also, as	adv,conj	[osi]		• Tu peux le faire, aussi. You can do it, too.	Tu peux le faire, aussi.		68. aussi From Old French ausi, from Latin aliud sic (“another thing thus”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
69	voir	to see	v	[vwaʀ]					69. voir From Old French veoir, veir, from earlier vedeir, from Latin vidēre, present active infinitive of videō, from Proto-Italic *widēō, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *weyd-.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
70	oh	oh	intj	[o]						[ ]	[ ]	[ ]
71	même	same, even, self	adj(f),adv,pro	[mɛm]					71. même From Middle French mesme, from Old French mesme, earlier meïsme, from Vulgar Latin *metipsimus, from Latin -met + ipse + -issimus. Cognates include Bourguignon moîme, Spanish mismo, Portuguese mesmo and Italian medesimo.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
72	maintenant	now	adv	[mɛ͂t(ə)nɑ͂]		• Je vais bien maintenant. I'm feeling fine now. • Si pas maintenant, alors quand? If not now, then when ? • Tout va bien maintenant. Everything's all right now. • Si pas maintenant, quand? If not now, when ?	Je vais bien maintenant. Si pas maintenant, alors quand? Tout va bien maintenant. Si pas maintenant, quand?		72. maintenant From maintenir +‎ -ant. Equivalent to main +‎ tenant.	[1]	[2]	[3]
73	le deux	two	det,nmi	[dø]					73. deux From Middle French deux, from Old French deus, from Latin duōs, masculine accusative of duo, from Proto-Italic *duō, from Proto-Indo-European *dwóh₁.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
74	autre	other	det,nadj(f),pro	[otʀ]		• Autre chose? Anything else ? • Où sont les autres? Where are the others ?	Autre chose? Où sont les autres?		74. autre From Old French altre, autre, from Latin alter, alterum, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *h₂élteros.	[1]	[2]	[3]
75	peu	little	adv	[pø]					75. peu From Old French poi, from Latin paucus, from Proto-Italic *paukus, ultimately from the Proto-Indo-European *peh₂w- (“few”, “little”). Compare Catalan poc, Italian poco, Portuguese Portuguese pouco, Spanish Spanish poco.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
76	quelque	some	adv,adj,det	[kɛlk]					76. quelque quel +‎ que	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
77	le temps	time	nm(pl)	[tɑ͂]		• Il est temps. It's about time. • Je le fais tout le temps. I do that all the time. • Comment est le temps? How is the weather ? • Il y a un temps pour tout. There is a right time for everything. • Il fait ça tout le temps. He does this all the time.	Il est temps. Je le fais tout le temps. Comment est le temps? Il y a un temps pour tout. Il fait ça tout le temps.		77. temps From Old French temps and its variants, from Latin tempus, from Proto-Indo-European *tempos (“stretch”), from the root *temp- (“to stretch, string”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
78	toujours	always	adv	[tuʒuʀ]		• Il est toujours avec moi. He is always with me. • Je le fais toujours. I still do that. • Je fais toujours la même chose. I always do the same thing.	Il est toujours avec moi. Je le fais toujours. Je fais toujours la même chose.		78. toujours From Middle French tousjours, from Old French toz jorz, tuzjurz (“without ceasing”, literally “all days”), equivalent to tous +‎ jours (compare Dutch altijd (“always”), Danish altid (“always”)). Replaced Old French sempres (“always”), from Latin semper.	[1]	[2]	[3]
79	encore	again, yet	adv	[ɑ͂kɔʀ]		• Il est encore ici. He is still here. • Encore merci pour tout. Thanks again for everything. • Je le fais encore. I still do that. • Je fais encore ça de temps en temps. I still do that from time to time.	Il est encore ici. Encore merci pour tout. Je le fais encore. Je fais encore ça de temps en temps.		79. encore Probably from Late Latin in hanc hōram (“until this hour”). Compare Occitan encara, Italian ancora.	[1]	[2]	[3]
80	notre	our	det	[nɔtʀ, no]					80. notre From Old French nostre, Latin noster, nostrum, nostra(m), from Proto-Italic *nosteros.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
81	besoin	need	nm	[bəzwɛ͂]					81. besoin From Middle French, Old French besoing; can be seen as a masculine variant of besogne, from Old French besonge, from Old Frankish *bisunnija, from *sunnijōn (“to look after”) (whence soigner), possibly through a Vulgar Latin intermediate *bisonium. Compare Italian bisogno.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
82	un accord	agreement	nm	[akɔʀ]					82. accord Deverbal of accorder.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
83	la vie	life	nf	[vi]		• Je vous dois la vie. I owe you my life. • Je lui dois la vie. I owe him my life.	Je vous dois la vie. Je lui dois la vie.		83. vie 1 From Old French vie, from Latin vīta, from Proto-Italic *gʷītā. Ultimately from Latin via. Compare voie.	[1]	[2]	[3]
84	aller	to go	nm,v	[ale]		• Je vais bien. I am fine. • Tu peux y aller. You can go there. • Vous allez bien. You're all right. • Allons le dire aux autres. Let's go tell the others. • Tout allait très bien. Everything was going great.	Je vais bien. Tu peux y aller. Vous allez bien. Allons le dire aux autres. Tout allait très bien.		84. aller A suppletive verb; Latin vādō (“go”) supplies the present tense forms and īre, present active infinitive of eō, supplies the future and conditional.	[1]	[2]	[3]
85	la fois	time, times	nf(pl)	[fwa]					85. fois 1 From Middle French foys, from Old French foiz, feiz, from Latin vices, plural of the noun vicis. Inflected form	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
86	sans	without	prep	[sɑ͂]					86. sans From Old French sans, senz, sens, from Latin sine conflated with absentia in the sense 'without'. Cognates include Spanish sin, Portuguese sem, Italian senza, Catalan sens, sense.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
87	donc	so, then, therefore, thus	conj	[dɔ͂k]					87. donc From Middle French donc, variant of doncques, from Old French donkes (“then”). Of uncertain and disputed origin. Perhaps an apheresis of adonc, from Latin ad-tunc, or a blend of Latin dum (“while”) + tum, tunc (“then”). Compare also Italian dunque.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
88	le monde	world, people	nm	[mɔ͂d]					88. monde 1 From Latin mundus (“world”). From Latin mundus (“pure; clean”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
89	avant	before; forward	adji,adv,nm,prep	[avɑ͂]					89. avant From Middle French, from Old French avant (“before, prior in time, forward”), from Late Latin abante (“before, in front of”) (compare Classical Latin ante (“before, in front of”)), from Latin ab (“of, from”) + ante (“before”). More at ante.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
90	sûr	sure	adj	[syʀ]		• Je suis sûr. I am sure. • Nous pouvons être sûrs de cela. We can be certain of that. • Je suis sûre de pouvoir le faire. I'm sure that I can do that.	Je suis sûr. Nous pouvons être sûrs de cela. Je suis sûre de pouvoir le faire.		90. sûr From Old French seür, inherited from Latin sēcūrus.	[1]	[2]	[3]
91	trop	too much, too many	adv	[tʀo]					91. trop From Middle French trop, from Old French trop (“unreasonably excessive”), from Frankish *thorp (“a cluster, agglomeration', also 'collection of houses, village”), from Proto-Germanic *þurpą (“village”), from Proto-Indo-European *trab-, *treb- (“dwelling, room”). Cognate with Old Saxon thorp (“village”), Old High German thorf (“village”), Old English þorp (“village”). More at thorp, troop.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
92	parler	to speak	nm,v	[paʀle]		• Je dois parler avec toi. I must talk with you. • Il parle vraiment bien. He speaks really well. • Ne lui en parle pas. Don't tell her about it. • Parle avec moi. Talk to me.	Je dois parler avec toi. Il parle vraiment bien. Ne lui en parle pas. Parle avec moi.		92. parler From Middle French parler (“to speak or talk”), from Old French parler (“to talk; to speak”), from Vulgar Latin *paraulare (“to speak”), from Late Latin parabolare, from Latin parabola (“comparison”), from Ancient Greek παραβολή (parabolḗ), from παραβάλλω (parabállō, “to compare”), from παρά (pará, “beside”) + βάλλω (bállō, “to throw”).	[1]	[2]	[3]

94	la personne	person, people, anybody, anyone, nobody	nf,pro	[pɛʀsɔn]		• Personne ne peut faire ça. No one can do that. • Cette personne est comme moi. That person is like me. • Personne ne dit rien. No one said anything. • Personne ne dit plus ça. No one says that anymore.	Personne ne peut faire ça. Cette personne est comme moi. Personne ne dit rien. Personne ne dit plus ça.		94. personne From Latin persona.	[1]	[2]	[3]

98	un homme	man	nm	[ɔm]		• Je suis un homme. I am a man.	Je suis un homme.		98. homme From Middle French homme, from Old French home, hom, hume, homme, etc, from Latin homō, hominem (with the loss of the -in- syllable), from Old Latin hemō, from Proto-Italic *hemō, from Proto-Indo-European *ǵʰmṓ (“earthling”). Compare Catalan home, Italian uomo, Portuguese homem, Romanian om, Sardinian ómine, Neapolitan hommo, Spanish hombre. Compare also French on, derived from the nominative of Latin homō.	[1]	[2]	[3]
99	la femme	woman, wife	nf	[fam]		• Comment va ta femme? How's your wife doing ? • Ta femme est ici. Your wife is here. • Je connais ces femmes. I know those women.	Comment va ta femme? Ta femme est ici. Je connais ces femmes.		99. femme From Middle French femme, from Old French fame, femme, feme, from Latin fēmina, from Proto-Indo-European *dʰeh₁-m̥h₁n-éh₂ (“(the one) nursing, breastfeeding”), derivation of the verbal root *dʰeh₁(y)- (“to suck, suckle”). Various spellings such as feme, fame and fenme were used in Old French.	[1]	[2]	[3]

101	vrai	true	adv,nadj	[vʀɛ]		• Tout est vrai. It's all true. • Ça peut bien être vrai. It may well be true. • Son histoire semble vraie. His story sounds true. • Toutes ces choses sont vraies. 106	beaucoup	a lot of, many	adv	[boku]		• Je veux beaucoup plus. I want much more. • Il y a encore beaucoup à faire. There's still a lot to be done.	Je veux beaucoup plus. Il y a encore beaucoup à faire.		106. beaucoup From Old French biau cop, first attested circa 1210.[1] Equivalent to beau (“nice, beautiful”) +‎ coup (“hit, strike”). The latter word also means “helping of soup or beverage”, first attested circa 1375, which sense may have triggered or reinforced beaucoup to mean “a lot”.	[1]	[2]	[3]

110	la fille	girl, daughter	nf	[fij]		• Tu es ma fille. You are my daughter. • Il avait une fille. He had one daughter. • Comment va ta fille? How is your daughter ? • Je connais ces filles. I know those girls. • Où sont les autres filles? Where are the other girls ?	Tu es ma fille. Il avait une fille. Comment va ta fille? Je connais ces filles. Où sont les autres filles?		110. fille (daughter): From Middle French fille, from Old French fille, from Latin fīlia. (slang, prostitute): By ellipsis of the euphemisms fille des rues (“girl of the streets”), fille de joie (“girl of joy”), fille publique (“public girl”), and others like them that signify 'prostitute'. 121	prendre	to take	v	[pʀɑ͂dʀ]		• Tu peux prendre ton temps. You can take your time. • Je prendrai du gâteau. I'll have some cake. • La maison prit feu. The house caught fire. • Prends ça. Take this. 122	le monsieur	mister, sir, gentleman	nm	[məsjø, mesjø]					122. monsieur From mon (“my”) + sieur, from the oblique case of Old French sire (cf. also seignor), ultimately from Latin senior.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
123	savoir	to know	nm,v	[savwaʀ]					123. savoir From Old French savoir, saveir, from Vulgar Latin *sapēre, from Latin sapĕre (“to taste”) (and 'to know' in Late Latin, by influence of the adjective sapiēns (“wise”)), present active infinitive of sapiō. Ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *seh₁p- (“to try, to research”). The verb was for a long time spelled sçavoir from Middle French until the 18th century, by false regression to Classical Latin scīre 'to know'.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

158	la chance	luck; chance	nf	[ʃɑ͂s]		• Tu as encore une chance. You still have a chance. • Bonne chance. Good luck. • Voilà ma chance. Here's my chance. • Quels sont nos chances? What are our chances ? • Certaines personnes ont toutes les chances. Some people have all the luck.	Tu as encore une chance. Bonne chance. Voilà ma chance. Quels sont nos chances? Certaines personnes ont toutes les chances.		158. chance From Old French chance, cheance (“accident, chance, luck”), from Vulgar Latin *cadentia (“falling”), from Latin cadēns, from cadō (“I fall, I die”). Doublet of cadence, borrowed from Italian.	[1]	[2]	[3]

Cela pourrait être une bonne idée.		160. idée From Latin idea (“a (Platonic) idea; archetype”), from Ancient Greek ἰδέα (idéa, “notion, pattern”).	[1]	[2]	[3]

162	demain	tomorrow	adv,nm	[dəmɛ͂]		• Je vais la faire demain. I will do it tomorrow. • Il peut partir demain. He can leave tomorrow. • Tu fais quelque chose demain soir? Are you doing anything tomorrow night ? • Elle peut partir demain. She can leave tomorrow. • Il sera à la maison demain. He will be at home tomorrow.	Je vais la faire demain. Il peut partir demain. Tu fais quelque chose demain soir? Elle peut partir demain. 173	le sens	sense, meaning	nm(pl)	[sɑ͂s]		• Cela fait vraiment sens. That really made sense.	Cela fait vraiment sens.		"173. sens 1 From Middle French, from Old French sens, sen, san (“sense, reason, direction”), partly from Latin sensus (“sense, sensation, feeling, meaning”), from sentiō (“feel, perceive”); partly from Frankish *sinn (“sense, reason, mental faculty, way, direction”), from Proto-Germanic *sinnaz (“mind, meaning”). 199	laisser	to leave, to let	v	[lese]					199. laisser From Middle French laisser, from Old French lesser, lessier, laissier (“to let, let go, leave”), from Latin laxō (“to relax, loosen”); partly from or influenced by Old High German lāzan (“to let, let go, leave”) (German lassen), from Proto-Germanic *lētaną (“to let, leave, leave alone”), from Proto-Indo-European *leh₁d- (“to leave, let”). Cognate with Old English lǣtan (“to allow, let go, leave, rent”), Gothic 𐌻𐌴𐍄𐌰𐌽 (lētan, “to release, forgive”). Conflated also with Old French laiier (“to leave, abandon, allow”) (compare Old Occitan laihar, laiar, Old Northern Italian lagare), also of Germanic origin, from Gothic 𐌻𐌰𐌲𐌾𐌰𐌽 (lagjan, “to lay, let lie, leave”), from Proto-Germanic *lagjaną (“to lay”). More at let, lay.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

228	pouvoir	can, to be able to	nm,v	[puvwaʀ]					228. pouvoir From Middle French povoir, from Old French povoir, pooir, from early Old French poeir, from Vulgar Latin *potēre (“to be able”), *possō for Classical Latin posse, present active infinitive of possum. 233	un enfant, une enfant	child	nm,nf,adj(f)	[ɑ͂fɑ͂]		• Même un enfant sait cela. Even a child knows that. • Mon enfant était dans la voiture. My kid was in the car. • Même un enfant peut le faire. Even a child can do it. • Même un enfant peut faire ça. Even a child can do that.	Même un enfant sait cela. Mon enfant était dans la voiture. Même un enfant peut le faire. Même un enfant peut faire ça.		233. enfant From Middle French enfant, from Old French enfant/enfes, probably borrowed from Latin īnfāns, īnfāntem, according to the Trésor de la Langue Française.	[1]	[2]	[3]

240	la chambre	bedroom, chamber	nf	[ʃɑ͂bʀ]		• Ma chambre est très petite. My room is very small. • Allez dans votre chambre! Go to your room ! • La chambre est assez petite. Vous avez le droit de savoir.		241. droit Inherited from Old French droit (spelled dreit in Early Old French), inherited from Vulgar Latin *drēctus, syncopated form of Latin dīrectus. 301	tomber	to fall	v	[tɔ͂be]		• Laisse tomber! Drop it ! • Je suis tombé amoureux de toi. I fell in love with you. • L'année prochaine mon anniversaire tombera un dimanche. Next year my birthday will fall on Sunday. • Il est tombé amoureux de son meilleur ami. He fell in love with his best friend.	Laisse tomber! Je suis tombé amoureux de toi. L'année prochaine mon anniversaire tombera un dimanche. Il est tombé amoureux de son meilleur ami.		301. tomber From Middle French tomber, from Old French tumber, from Frankish *tūmōn (“to rotate, reel, sway”), from Proto-Germanic *tūmōną (“to turn, rotate”), of uncertain origin. Cognate with Old High German tūmōn (“to rotate, turn round”), Old Norse tumba (“to fall, tumble”), Old English tumbian (“to dance about, leap, tumble”). More at tumb.	[1]	[2]	[3]

371	le calme	calm	nadj(f)	[kalm]		• Je suis calme. I am calm. • Il nous dit de rester calme. He told us to keep quiet. • Tout est calme. All is quiet. • Reste calme. 373	le verre	glass, cup	nm	[vɛʀ]		• Prenez un verre avec moi. Have a drink with me. • Mon verre est plein. My glass is full. • J'apporte des verres. I'll bring the glasses. • Où sont les verres? From Middle French ferme (“farm, farm buildings”), from Old French ferme (“lease for working, rent, farm”), from Medieval Latin ferma, firma (“rent, tax, tribute, farm”), from Old English feorm (“rent, provision, supplies, feast”), from Proto-Germanic *firmō, *firhuma- (“means of living, subsistence”), from *firhu- (“life force, body, being”), from Proto-Indo-European *perkʷ- (“life, force, strength, tree”). Related to Old English feorh (“life, spirit”), Gothic 𐍆𐌰𐌹𐍂𐍈𐌿𐍃 (fairƕus, “the world”). Compare also Old English feormehām (“farm”), feormere (“purveyor”).	[1]	[2]	[3]

435	la carte	card, map	nf	[kaʀt]		• Ceci est une carte. This is a map. • Prenez une carte. Take a card. • Je veux jouer aux cartes. I want to play cards. • Prends deux cartes de ton choix. Take any two cards you like.	Ceci est une carte. Prenez une carte. Je veux jouer aux cartes. Il nous faut commencer au début.		444. début From Middle French, derivative of desbuter (“to move, begin”), from des- + but (“mark, goal”), from Old French but (“aim, goal, end, target”), either from Old French butte (“mound, knoll, target”), from Frankish *but (“stump, log”), or from Old Norse bútr (“log, stump, butt”); both from Proto-Germanic *butą (“end, piece”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰewd- (“to beat, push”).[1] Cognate with Old English butt (“tree stump”). 457	gagner	to win, earn	v	[gaɲe]		• Notre équipe peut gagner. Our team can win. • Je gagne bien ma vie. I make a good living. • Je voulais que tu gagnes. I wanted you to win. • Qui gagne? 459	tirer	to pull, fire	v	[tiʀe]					455. tirer From Middle French tirer (“to draw, draw a sword”), from Old French tirer (“to draw, pull out with great effort, snatch violently, tear away”), from Medieval Latin, from Vulgar Latin *tīrō, tīrāre, of uncertain origin, but probably Germanic; possibly from Gothic *𐍄𐌹𐍂𐌰𐌽 (*tiran, “to tear away, remove”), from Proto-Germanic *teraną (“to tear, tear apart”), from Proto-Indo-European *der- (“to tear, tear apart”). Compare Italian tirare, Catalan, Portuguese, and Spanish tirar. If derived from the Germanic word, cognate with Gothic 𐌳𐌹𐍃𐍄𐌰𐌹𐍂𐌰𐌽 (distairan, “to tear apart”), Gothic 𐌲𐌰𐍄𐌰𐌹𐍂𐌰𐌽 (gatairan, “to tear down, remove”), German zerren (“to tug”). Related to tear. Alternatively from a reduction of Old French martirier, from Late Latin *martyrāre.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

J'ai une avocate.		456. avocat 1 Borrowed from Latin advocātus. Compare the past participle avoué. From Spanish aguacate, from Classical Nahuatl āhuacatl. 501	le rouge	red	nadj(f)	[ʀuʒ]		• Le téléphone est rouge. The telephone is red. • Ma nouvelle voiture est rouge. My new car is red. • Ton visage est rouge. Ton visage est rouge. J'ai une paire de chaussures rouges. Ses joues étaient rouges.		496. rouge From Middle French rouge, from Old French roge, rouge, from Latin rubeus.	[1]	[2]	[3]
502	retourner	to return, go back	v	[ʀ(ə)tuʀne]		• Retourne dans ta chambre. Return to your room.	Retourne dans ta chambre.		497. retourner Old French retorner, from re- + torner	[1]	[2]	[3]

504	le bateau	boat, ship	nm	[bato]		• Ils avaient un bateau. They had a boat. • Où est le capitaine de ce bateau? Where is the captain of this ship ? • On peut encore voir le bateau. The boat can still be seen. • Quelques bateaux sont sur le lac. Some boats are on the lake.	Ils avaient un bateau. Où est le capitaine de ce bateau? On peut encore voir le bateau. Quelques bateaux sont sur le lac.		499. bateau From Old French batel: Anglo-Norman bat, from Old English bāt (English boat) + suffix from Latin -ellus. It displaced the native word nef, which comes from Latin navis.	[1]	[2]	[3]
505	stupide	stupid, silly, bemused	adj(f)	[stypid]					500. stupide Borrowed from Latin stupidus (“struck senseless, amazed”), from stupeō (“be amazed or confounded, be struck senseless”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)tup- (“to wonder”), from *(s)tu- (“to stand, stay”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
506	le médecin, la médecin	physician, doctor	nm	[medsɛ͂]		• Je suis médecin. I'm a doctor. • Tu devrais voir le médecin. You should see the doctor. • Je veux un médecin. I want a doctor. • Ils sont médecins. They are doctors. • Je viens d'une famille de médecins. I come from a family of doctors.	Je suis médecin. Tu devrais voir le médecin. Je veux un médecin. Ils sont médecins. Je viens d'une famille de médecins.		501. médecin Derived regressively from *médeciner. Replaced Old French mire, mege, meide, meie, etc, from Latin medicus.	[1]	[2]	[3]
507	la balle	ball, bullet	nf	[bal]					502. balle 1 From Middle French balle from Northern Italian balla (“ball”), from Lombardic *palla, *balla (“ball”), from Proto-Germanic *ballô (“ball”), from Proto-Indo-European *bholn- (“bubble”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰel- (“to blow, swell, inflate”). Akin to Old High German ballo, bal (“ball”) (German Ballen (“bale”); Ball (“ball”)). More at ball. From Middle French balle (“large bundle, package”), from Old French bale (“rolled-up bundle, packet of goods”), from Frankish *balla, from Proto-Germanic *ballô (“ball”), from Proto-Indo-European *bholn- (“bubble”), from Proto-Indo-European *bhel- (“to swell, inflate, blow”). Akin to Old High German balo 'pack, bale', balla (“ball”), Middle High German bal, balle (“clench, bale, ball”) (German Ballen (“bale”)). More at bale. From Gaulish *balu.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
508	la faim	hungry	nf	[fɛ͂]					503. faim From Old French faim, fain, from Latin famēs (“hunger”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰH- (“to disappear”). Compare Galician fame, Portuguese fome, Italian fame and Romanian foame.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
509	le contrôle	control	nm	[kɔ͂tʀol]		• Le contrôle était facile. The test was easy.	Le contrôle était facile.		504. contrôle An haplology of Middle French contrerole, a borrowing from Medieval Latin contrarotulum (“a counter-roll or register used to verify accounts”), from Latin contra (“against, opposite”) + Latin rotulus, rotula (“roll, a little wheel”), diminutive of rota (“a wheel”).	[1]	[2]	[3]

522	le gauche, la gauche	left	nadj(f)	[goʃ]		• Elle écrit de la main gauche. She writes with her left hand.	Elle écrit de la main gauche.		517. gauche From gauchir (“warp, distort”), a conflation of Old French gauchier (“tread”) (from Frankish *walkijan, *walkan, cognate with English walk) + Old French guenchir (“deviate”) (from Frankish *wenkijan (“to sway, falter”)). Gauche replaced the original word for 'left', senestre, in the sixteenth century.	[1]	[2]	[3]

545	joli	pretty, attractive	adj	[ʒɔli]		• Tu es jolie en noir. You look good in black. • Joli coup! Nice shot ! • Sa fille est très jolie. Her daughter is very pretty. • Elle a un joli visage. Ils nous connaissent.		563. connaître From Old French conoistre, from Latin cognōscere, present active infinitive of cognōscō (probably through a Vulgar Latin *connōscere).	[1]	[2]	[3]
569	la loi	law	nf	[lwa]		• Tu connais la loi. You know the law.	Tu connais la loi.		564. loi From Middle French loy, from Old French loi, lei, from Latin lēgem, accusative singular of lēx, from Proto-Italic *lēg-, from Proto-Indo-European *leǵ-s < *leǵ-.	[1]	[2]	[3]
570	le gamin	kid	nm	[gamɛ͂, in]		• Hors de mon chemin, gamin. Out of my way, boy. • Je ferais tout pour ces gamins. I'd do anything for those kids.	Hors de mon chemin, gamin. Je ferais tout pour ces gamins.			[1]	[2]	[ ]
571	le professeur, la professeur	professor, teacher	nm,nf	[pʀɔfesœʀ]		• Je suis professeur. I'm a teacher. • Écoutez ce que dit le professeur. Listen to what the teacher says. • Notre professeur aime sa nouvelle voiture. Our teacher likes his new car. • Elle est professeur. She's a professor. • Il parle comme s'il était un professeur. He talks as if he were a teacher.	Je suis professeur. Écoutez ce que dit le professeur. Notre professeur aime sa nouvelle voiture. Elle est professeur. Il parle comme s'il était un professeur.		566. professeur Borrowed from Latin professor.	[1]	[2]	[3]
572	le froid	cold	nadj	[fʀwa]		• Il commence à faire froid. It's starting to cool off. • Il faisait froid hier. It was cold yesterday. • Il commence à faire froid ici. It's starting to get cold here. • Garde la tête froide. Keep a cool head.	Il commence à faire froid. Il faisait froid hier. Il commence à faire froid ici. Garde la tête froide.		567. froid From Old French froit, freid, inherited from Latin frīgidus (“cold”) (through a syncopated Vulgar Latin or Late Latin form frigdus, fricdus, attested in the Appendix Probi, or fridus, on a Pompeian inscription). Doublet of frigide, a later borrowing.	[1]	[2]	[3]
573	la forme	form	nf	[fɔʀm]					568. forme From Old French forme, borrowed from Latin fōrma, possibly cognate with Ancient Greek μορφή (morphḗ).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
574	normal	normal	adj	[nɔʀmal]		• Tout est normal. Everything is normal.	Tout est normal.		569. normal Borrowed from Latin normālis. Synchronically analysable as norme +‎ -al.	[1]	[2]	[3]
575	le but	goal, aim, objective, purpose	nm	[by(t)]		• Quel est son but? What is its purpose ?	Quel est son but?		570. but 1 From Middle French but (“mark, goal”), from Old French but (“aim, goal, end, target”), from Old French butte (“mound, knoll, target”), from Frankish *but (“stump, log”), or from Old Norse bútr (“log, stump, butt”); both from Proto-Germanic *butą (“end, piece”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰÀud- (“to beat, push”). The semantic development from 'mound' to 'target' is likely from martial training practice (see target). Cognate with Old English butt (“tree stump”). More at butt. From boire.	[1]	[2]	[3]
576	une offre	offer	nf	[ɔfʀ]		• Je vous offre un choix. I'm offering you a choice. • Faites une offre. Make an offer.	Je vous offre un choix. Faites une offre.			[1]	[2]	[ ]
577	le conseil	advice, counsel, council	nm	[kɔ͂sɛj]		• Je vais suivre ton conseil. I will follow your advice. • Écoute mon conseil! Take my advice ! • J'apprécie tous tes conseils. I appreciate all your advice. • Nous voulons vos conseils. We want your advice.	Je vais suivre ton conseil. Écoute mon conseil! J'apprécie tous tes conseils. Nous voulons vos conseils.		572. conseil From Latin cōnsilium.	[1]	[2]	[3]

That man is dangerous. • Ça pourrait être dangereux. It could be dangerous. • C'est une mission dangereuse. This is a dangerous mission.	Ça peut être dangereux. Le monde est dangereux. 582	la boîte	box	nf	[bwat]		• Regarde dans la boîte. Look into the box. • Prends la boîte. Get the box. • Ferme la boîte. Close the box. • Tiens la boîte des deux mains. 585	le danger	danger	nm	[dɑ͂ʒe]		• Elle est hors de danger. She is out of danger. • Ma vie était en danger. My life was in danger. • Nous sommes hors de danger. We are free from danger. • Votre vie est en danger. Your life is in danger. • Sa vie est en danger. Her life is in danger.	Elle est hors de danger. Ma vie était en danger. Nous sommes hors de danger. Votre vie est en danger. Sa vie est en danger.		579. danger From Old French dangier, alteration of Old French dongier (due to association with Latin damnum (“damage”)) from Vulgar Latin *domniārium (“authority, power”) from Latin dominus (“lord, master”). Tes idées sont étranges.		628. étrange From Middle French estrange, from Old French estrange, from Latin extrāneus.	[1]	[2]	[3]

636	le signe	sign	nm	[siɲ]		• Signe juste ici. Just sign here. • Signe sur cette ligne. Sign on this line. • Signe ça. Sign this. • Signe juste ça. Just sign this. • Signe ici. Sign here. 644	le soin	care	nm	[swɛ͂]		• Prends soin de toi. Take care of yourself. • Prends bien soin de toi. Take good care of yourself. • Prends soin de ta santé. 852	ancien	ancient; former	adj,nm	[ɑ͂sjɛ͂]		• Ce livre est très ancien. That book is very old. • Le musée présente une exposition d'armes anciennes. The museum has an exhibit of ancient weapons.	Ce livre est très ancien. Le musée présente une exposition d'armes anciennes.		843. ancien From Middle French ancien, from Old French ancien, from a Vulgar Latin root *anteanus or *antianu, from Latin ante. As the word does not completely conform to the expected phonetic evolution, it may have been semi-learned and used initially by clerics who were aware of the Vulgar Latin word (which does not appear until the (Old) French one does). See also the related Old and Middle French ains.	[1]	[2]	[3]

942	sourire	smile, to smile	nm,v	[suʀiʀ]		• Elle était tout sourire. She was all smiles. • Ton sourire me rend toujours heureux. Your smile always makes me happy. • Le professeur sourit. The professor smiled. • La fortune lui sourit. Fortune smiled on him. • Elle sourit à son bébé. She smiled at her baby.	Elle était tout sourire. Ton sourire me rend toujours heureux. Elle sourit à son bébé.		933. sourire From Old French, from Vulgar Latin *subrīdĕre, from Latin subrīdēre, present active infinitive of subrīdeō (“I smile”). 958	le gâteau	cake	nadj	[gɑto]		• Essaye ce gâteau. Try this cake. • Vous pouvez vous servir du gâteau. Please help yourself to the cake. • Ma mère fait un gâteau pour mon père. 960	couper	to cut	v	[kupe]		• Tu devrais aller te faire couper les cheveux. You should go and have your hair cut. • Coupez le fil rouge. Cut the red wire. • Coupez le gâteau avec ce couteau. Coupez le gâteau avec ce couteau.		951. couper From Old French coper, colper (“to cut off”), probably, derived from cop (“blow”), colp (modern coup), with its meaning coming from the idea of cutting off with a blow. It may correspond to a Vulgar Latin verb *colpāre, syncopated form of *colaphāre, from Latin colaphus (compare Old Spanish golpar, colpar, Old Portuguese golpar, golbar). Alternatively, possibly from Vulgar Latin *cuppāre (“to behead”), from Latin caput (“head”), although this is unlikely.	[1]	[2]	[3]

1019	réparer	to repair, fix, correct, make up	v	[ʀepaʀe]		• Je peux le réparer. I can fix it. • Veuillez réparer ceci. Please repair this. • Il vous faut réparer ça. 1025	le parc	park	nm	[paʀk]		• Je suis allé au parc hier. I went to the park yesterday. • Il aime marcher dans le parc. He likes walking in the park. • Je suis allé au parc ce matin. Akin to Old High German pfarrih 'fencing, enclosure' (German Pferch 'sheepfold'), Dutch perk, park 'garden, park', Old English pearruc (“enclosure”). More at paddock.	[1]	[2]	[3]

1028	le jardin	garden	nm	[ʒaʀdɛ͂]		• Je suis dans le jardin. I am in the garden. • J'adore votre jardin. I love your garden. • Elles sont au jardin. They're in the garden. • Le jardin est en face de la maison. The garden is in front of the house. • Mon père est dans le jardin. My father is in the garden.	Je suis dans le jardin. J'adore votre jardin. Elles sont au jardin. Le jardin est en face de la maison. Mon père est dans le jardin.		1018. jardin From Middle French jardin, from Old French jardin, ('garden, enclosure', probably from Vulgar Latin or early Gallo-Romance hortus gardinus, from Old Frankish *gardin, oblique case of *gardō (“enclosure, yard”) (compare also Old French jart (“garden”))), from Proto-Germanic *gardô (“enclosure, garden, house”), from Proto-Indo-European *gʰordʰos (“hedge, enclosure”), from Proto-Indo-European *gʰerdʰ- (“court, yard”). Cognate with Old High German gart, garto (“garden, enclosure, yard”), Old English ġeard (“garden, yard, fence, enclosure”). Cognate with English garden, which was derived from an Anglo-Norman/Old Northern French variant. More at yard.	[1]	[2]	[3]
1029	falloir	to take, require, need	v	[falwaʀ]					1019. falloir From Old French faloir, from an earlier falleir, from a changing of Old French faillir after its third person singular, faut, earlier falt (from Latin fallit), based off the model of valoir. Faillir derives in turn from Vulgar Latin fallīre, from Latin fallere, fallō. Compare Franco-Provençal falêr from a similar development in Old Franco-Provençal.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

The later spelling in Old French thus reflects the influence of the spelling of phantasma, the standard Latin form.	[1]	[2]	[3]

1076	agréable	pleasant, nice, agreeable	nadj(f)	[agʀeabl]		• C'est très agréable. That feels very nice. • Il a une voix agréable. He has a pleasant voice. • Ce fut assez agréable. Ce fut assez agréable. J'ai passé une très agréable soirée. Elle a une agréable voix.		1065. agréable agréer +‎ -able	[1]	[2]	[3]

1081	la perte	the loss	nf	[pɛʀt]		• Ce fut une perte de temps. It was a waste of time. • Cette réunion était une perte de temps. That meeting was a waste of time. • C'est une telle perte de temps. 1094	le mensonge	the lie	nm	[mɑ͂sɔ͂ʒ]		• C'était un mensonge. That was a lie. • C'était un mensonge, bien sûr. It was a lie, of course. • Elle doit avoir dit un mensonge. She must have told a lie. • Je suis fatigué de tous leurs mensonges. I'm fed up with all their lies.	C'était un mensonge. C'était un mensonge, bien sûr. Elle doit avoir dit un mensonge. Je suis fatigué de tous leurs mensonges.		1083. mensonge From Middle French mensonge, from Old French mençonge, mençunge, probably from a Vulgar Latin *mentionica, from Late Latin mentiō, mentiōnem (in the sense of 'lie' rather than 'mention'), probably formed from haplology of a root *mentītiō, from Latin mentītus, past participle of mentior. Cognate to Occitan messorga, messonja, mensònega; compare also Italian menzogna, Romansh manzögna and Old French mensoigne, from a different but related root, and Romanian minciună.	[1]	[2]	[3]

1098	le pantalon	trousers, pants	nm	[pɑ͂talɔ͂]		• C'est mon pantalon. Those are my pants. • Ce pantalon me va bien. These pants fit me well. • Ton pantalon est sale. Où est mon pantalon?		1087. pantalon From Italian Pantalone; a character from the commedia dell'arte whose hose were portrayed as being down around his feet. 1134	un aveugle, une aveugle	blind	nadj(f)	[avœgl]					1123. aveugle From Middle French aveugle < Old French avogle, from Late Latin *ab oculis (“without eyes”), possibly a calque of Greek ex ops or from a Latin construction viduus or vacuus ab oculis. Less likely from a Latin *alboculus, from albus + oculus. The current French form is either an exception to the normal sound shift from Latin '-cl-' or a semi-learned term; cf. the dialectal and popular aveuil (older aveule, avule). See also œil. 1149	le vert	green	nadj	[vɛʀ]		• Le feu est vert. The light is green. • Heureusement, j'ai la main verte. Fortunately, I have a green thumb. • Les arbres sont verts. J'aime la couleur verte. La table est verte.		1138. vert From Old French vert, from Vulgar Latin virdis, virdem, from Latin viridis, viridem.	[1]	[2]	[3]

1158	virer	to turn, change, transfer, kick out	v	[viʀe]		• Je pourrais te virer pour ça. I could fire you for that. • Tu fais ça et je te vire. You do that and I'll fire you.	Je pourrais te virer pour ça. Tu fais ça et je te vire.		1147. virer From Vulgar Latin *virō, probably from Latin vibrō (in which case it is a doublet of vibrer) or possibly from an alteration of gȳrō. Compare Italian virare, Spanish virar. Or, possibly from Gaulish *viru, ‘to deviate, veer off,’ itself derived from viros, ‘round, crooked.’	[1]	[2]	[3]
1159	la pluie	rain	nf	[plɥi]		• On a eu beaucoup de pluie hier. We had a lot of rain yesterday. • Nous avons eu beaucoup de pluie cette année. We've had a lot of rain this year. 1232	crier	to shout, scream, cry out	v	[kʀije]					1219. crier From Old French crier, from Medieval Latin crīdāre (“to clamour, cry out, publish, proclaim”) (compare Spanish gritar, Catalan and Occitan cridar, Italian gridare). Perhaps from Latin quiritare (“to shriek, wail”) (--Diez), or from Frankish *krītan (“to cry out, shout, proclaim”), from Proto-Germanic *krītaną (“to cry out, shout”), from Proto-Indo-European *greid- (“to shout”). Akin to Middle Dutch crīten, krīten (Dutch krijten 'to cry, cry out'), Middle Low German krīten 'to shriek, cry out', Middle High German krīzen 'to cry out loudly' (German kreissen 'to wail in childbirth').	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

1379	la foule	crowd	nf	[ful]					1366. foule 1 From Middle French foule (“group of men, people collectively”), alteration (due to Middle French foule (“act of treading”)) of Old French foulc (“people, multitude, crowd, troop”), from Vulgar Latin, from Frankish *folc, *fulc (“crowd, multitude, people”), from Proto-Germanic *fulką (“collection or class of people, multitude; host of warriors”), perhaps from Proto-Indo-European *pleh₁- (“to fill”). Cognate with Old High German folc (“people collectively, nation”), Old English folc (“common people, troop, multitude”). More at folk. From Middle French foule (“the act of milling clothes or hats”) and fouler (“to trample, mill, fordo, mistreat”), from Old French foler (“to crush, act wickedly”), from Latin fullō (“I trample, I full”). More at full.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

1399	le curieux	curious	nadj(pl)	[kyʀjø, -jøz]		• C'est curieux. This is curious. • Je suis curieux. I am curious. • J'étais vraiment curieux. I was really curious. • J'étais juste curieux. I was just curious. • Je suis aussi curieux que vous. I'm as curious as you are.	C'est curieux. Je suis curieux. J'étais vraiment curieux. J'étais juste curieux. Je suis aussi curieux que vous.		1385. curieux Borrowed from Latin cūriōsus (“careful, attentive, inquisitive”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
1400	le mardi	Tuesday	nm	[maʀdi]					1386. mardi From Old French mardi, from Latin Martis diēs, variant of diēs Martis ('day of Mars').	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

1402	la médecine	medecine, medical science	nf	[medsin]					1388. médecine From Old French medecine, from Latin medicīna.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
1403	le ménage	housekeeping, housework	nm	[menaʒ]					1389. ménage From Old French manage, mainage, from manoir, maneir, maindre, from Latin manēre. The Old French forms maisnage, mesnage were influenced by the word maisnée, maisnede, from Vulgar Latin *mansionata (French maisonnée), from Latin mansiō (French maison).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
1404	soudain	sudden, suddenly	adj,adv	[sudɛ͂, ɛn]					1390. soudain From Old French sodein, from Vulgar Latin *subitānus, from Latin subitāneus (“sudden”), from subitus.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
1405	le ballon	ball	nm	[balɔ͂]		• Attrape le ballon. Catch the ball. • Le ballon est plein d'air. The balloon is filled with air. • Tiens le ballon des deux mains. Hold the ball with both hands.	Attrape le ballon. Le ballon est plein d'air. Tiens le ballon des deux mains.		1391. ballon From Middle French ballon from Northern Italian bal(l)one (compare Italian pallone (“large ball”)) from palla (“ball”), from Lombardic *palla (“ball”), perhaps influenced by the earlier Northern Italian balla, from Old French balle, from Frankish balla, both from Proto-Germanic *ballô (“ball”), *balluz, from Proto-Indo-European *bholn- (“bubble”), from *bhel- (“to blow, swell, inflate”). Akin to Old High German ballo, bal (“ball”) (German Ballen (“bale”); Ball (“ball”)). More at ball.	[1]	[2]	[3]

1412	réussir	to succeed	v	[ʀeysiʀ]		• Tu dois travailler dur pour réussir. You must work hard to succeed. • Son fils est certain de réussir. Her son will succeed for sure. • Elle réussit l'examen. She passed the examination. • Je réussis à ma première tentative. I succeeded in my first attempt.	Tu dois travailler dur pour réussir. Son fils est certain de réussir. Elle réussit l'examen. Je réussis à ma première tentative.		1398. réussir Back-formation from réussite (“success”), a borrowing from Italian riuscita (“result, outcome; success”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
1413	conseiller	adviser, to advise	nm,v	[kɔ͂seje]		• Tu ferais un bon conseiller. You'd make a good counselor. • Je vous conseille de vous changer. I advise you to change clothes. 1414	la cérémonie	ceremony	nf	[seʀemɔni]					1400. cérémonie From Latin caerimōnia, from caelum + munia.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
1415	brûler	to burn	v	[bʀyle]		• Ça va brûler. It will burn.	Ça va brûler.		1401. brûler From Middle French brusler “to burn” from Old French brusler, bruller (“to burn”), a conflation of bruir (“to burn”) (from Frankish *brōjan (“to burn, scald”), from Proto-Germanic *brōaną “to scald”, from Proto-Indo-European *bʰerw-, *bhrew- “to boil, seethe”), and usler (“to scorch”), from Latin ustulāre (“to scorch”). Compare also Italian bruciare, from a Vulgar Latin form *brusiāre, which is probably related, as well as brustolare. The initial -br- has had other origins proposed, such as from a Gaulish source, or from a corruption of a form *combustulāre, from a change of prefix of ambustulāre, influenced by combustus. Akin to German brühen (“to scald”), Dutch broeien (“to heat”). More at broil, brew.	[1]	[2]	[3]
1416	couvrir	to cover	v	[kuvʀiʀ]		• Je vais te couvrir. I'll cover for you.	Je vais te couvrir.		1402. couvrir From Old French covrir, inherited from Latin cooperīre, present active infinitive of cooperiō, from co- + operiō.	[1]	[2]	[3]

1503	le roman	novel	adj,nm	[ʀɔmɑ͂]		• J'aime son roman. I like her novel. • Ce roman m'ennuie. This novel bores me. • Il a commencé à écrire un roman. He has started to write a novel. • J'écris un roman. I'm writing a novel. • J'ai lu tous ses romans. I have read all his novels.	J'aime son roman. Ce roman m'ennuie. Il a commencé à écrire un roman. J'écris un roman. J'ai lu tous ses romans.		1489. roman 1 In the 19th century, borrowed from Latin romanus.[1] or from the French noun below [2], originally from Old French romanz (“common language”). From Old French romanz (“common language (as opposed to Latin)”), from Medieval Latin rōmānicē, Vulgar Latin *romanicē (“in the way of the Romans (as opposed to the Franks)”), from Latin rōmānicus < rōmānus.[3]. The meaning “common language” changed into “book in common language” and then into “adventure novel”.[1] See also romance, of the same ultimate origin but borrowed through Spanish.	[1]	[2]	[3]

1649	un étudiant	student	nadj	[etydjɑ͂, jɑ͂t]		• Ce sont mes étudiants. These are my students. • C'est un bon étudiant. He is a good student. • Je connais quelques étudiants de cette école. 1650	un orange, une orange	orange	adji,nf	[ɔʀɑ͂ʒ]					1635. orange Short form of late Old French pume orenge or pomme d'orenge, which was calqued after Old Italian melarancia (mela + arancia). 1651	la coïncidence	coincidence	nf	[kɔɛ͂sidɑ͂s]		• C'est une coïncidence. This is a coincidence. • C'était juste une coïncidence. It was just a coincidence. • Ce pourrait être une coïncidence. 1652	voyager	to travel	v	[vwajaʒe]		• J'aime voyager. I enjoy traveling. • Nous pouvons voyager ensemble. We can travel together. • Il adore voyager. He loves traveling. • Elle est assez grande pour voyager toute seule. She is old enough to travel by herself. • J'ai voyagé seul. I traveled by myself.	J'aime voyager. Nous pouvons voyager ensemble. 1653	fêter	to celebrate	v	[fete]		• Merci de m'aider à fêter mon anniversaire. Thank you for helping me celebrate my birthday.	Merci de m'aider à fêter mon anniversaire.		1638. fêter From Old French fester. Synchronically analysable as fête +‎ -er.	[1]	[2]	[3]
1654	un allemand	German	nadj	[almɑ͂]		• Je veux étudier l'allemand. I want to study German. • L'allemand est la meilleure langue du monde. German is the best language in the world. • Je parle un peu allemand. I speak a little German.	Je veux étudier l'allemand. L'allemand est la meilleure langue du monde. Je parle un peu allemand.		1639. allemand From Late Latin Alamannus or Alemannus (related to Alamans, ancient Germanic people for whom the name meant 'all men', 'all people', according to Asinius Quadratus). aleman became alemant by the addition of a terminal T of the singular objective case for adjectives of second class in Old French, and then alemand. The Latin word itself derives from the Old High German Alaman, from a Proto-Germanic *Alamanniz, likely from the roots *allaz (whence English all) and *manniz < *mann- (whence English man).	[1]	[2]	[3]
1655	le congé	holiday, time off, day off, notice	nm	[kɔ͂ʒe]		• Je suis en congé cette semaine. I am on holiday this week.	Je suis en congé cette semaine.		1640. congé From Old French congié, cungié, cunged, congiet, cumgiet, from Latin commeātus. As an architectural term, a Calque of Ancient Greek ἀποφυγή (apophugḗ, “a leave, an escape; an architectural feature”).	[1]	[2]	[3]

1708	la race	breed, race	nf	[ʀas]					1693. race From Italian razza, from Old High German reiza (“line”), or possibly from Arabic رَأْس‎ (raʾs, “head”). Alternatively, razza may have been borrowed from Old French haraz (“culture of horses”) as well. Another theory is that the Italian word came from Latin ratiō (the nominative, as opposed to ragione from the accusative ratiōnem, which nonetheless was attested with a similar sense to razza in the late Middle Ages; ratio also came to mean 'idea' or 'conception of something' in Ecclesiastical Latin), and underwent a change of gender later from an original form *razzo, or else derived ultimately from generātiō through apheresis. 1731	la panne	the breakdown, the failure (of a machine)	nf	[pan]		• J'avais une panne. I had a breakdown.	J'avais une panne.		1716. panne From Old French panne (“a fur lining; a warp resulting from such a lining, hence a breakdown”) from Medieval Latin panna, alteration of Latin penna (“quill”) from pinna (“feather, wing”). The transition of sense from 'feather/wing' to 'fur' is due to an associative analogy to the corresponding Frankish word *feder, which could mean both 'feather' and 'fur'; compare Old High German vëder, federe (“feather'/'fur”).	[1]	[2]	[3]

1822	rêver	to dream	v	[ʀeve, ʀɛve]		• J'ai dû rêver. I must've been dreaming. • Nous pouvons toutes rêver. We can all dream.	J'ai dû rêver. Nous pouvons toutes rêver.		1806. rêver From Middle French resver, from Old French resver (“to consider, reflect, be delirious”), of uncertain origin. The Trésor de la langue française informatisé links it back either to an unattested *esver (“to wander”) or to Latin *reexvadō, from re- +‎ ex- +‎ evadō[1]. The Französisches Etymologisches Wörterbuch links it back to *reexvagus, hence the same as the first proposal by the Trésor de la langue française informatisé[2].	[1]	[2]	[3]

Cognate with Swedish våg (“wave”), Middle Dutch waeghe, wage (“wave”), Old High German wāge (“wave”), Old English wǣg (“wave, billow, motion, flood”). More at waw, wave. From Middle French vague, from Latin vagus (“wandering, rambling, strolling, fig. uncertain, vague”).	[1]	[2]	[3]

Ces pommes sont grosses. Cette boîte est pleine de pommes. Je peux manger cette pomme?		1920. pomme From Latin poma, plural of pomum.	[1]	[2]	[3]

1939	la charité	charity	nf	[ʃaʀite]					1923. charité From Old French charité, carité, borrowing from or francization of Latin cāritās, cāritātem (“love, regard”) (or the variant chāritās), from carus (“dear”) (whence French cher), from Proto-Indo-European *kāro- (“dear”). (Watkins, 1969 et al.). See also the doublet cherté.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
1940	promener	to take for a walk, go for a walk	v	[pʀɔm(ə)ne]		• J'ai envie de me promener. I feel like taking a walk. • Je suis allé me promener avec mon fils. I went for a walk with my son. • Mon père va se promener chaque matin. My father takes a walk every morning. • Il promène son chien chaque matin. He walks his dog every morning. • Mon père se promène tous les jours. My father takes a walk every day.	J'ai envie de me promener. Je suis allé me promener avec mon fils. Mon père va se promener chaque matin. Il promène son chien chaque matin. Mon père se promène tous les jours.		1924. promener From Vulgar Latin prominare 'to drive forward', from prō (“forward”) +‎ mino (“I drive”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
1941	la méthode	method, procedure	nf	[metɔd]		• Ta méthode est meilleure. Your method is better. • C'est de loin la meilleure méthode. This is by far the best method.	Ta méthode est meilleure. C'est de loin la meilleure méthode.		1925. méthode Borrowed from Vulgar Latin methodus, from Ancient Greek μέθοδος (méthodos, “pursuit of knowledge, investigation, mode of prosecuting such inquiry, system”), from μετά (metá, “after”) + ὁδός (hodós, “way, motion, journey”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
1942	le câble	cable, wire	nm	[kɑbl]					1926. câble From cable, an Old Northern French (i.e. Old Norman or Picard) variant of chable, cheable, chaable, from Vulgar Latin *caplum, contracted form of Late Latin capulum, from Latin capiō. The Norman-Picard form, used primarily in a maritime sense, coexisted with the Francien dialect forms until replacing them by the 18th century. The Old French forms cheable and chaable were crossed with or influenced by the separate word chaable (“catapult”), from a Vulgar Latin *cadabulum.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

Akin to Middle High German grāzan (“to cry”), Old English grǣtan (“to weep, greet”), Old English grēotan (“to weep, lament”), Old Norse gráta (“to weep, groan”), Gothic 𐌲𐍂𐌴𐍄𐌰𐌽 (grētan, “to weep”). Je suis simplement franc.		2038. franc 1 From Middle French, from Old French franc (“free, genuine, sincere”), from Late Latin Franc (“a Frank”), from Frankish *Frank (“a Frank”), a name probably taken from Proto-Germanic *frankô, *frakkōn (“spear”), from Proto-Indo-European *prAng-, *prAgn- (“pole, stalk”). 2232	un automne	fall, autumn	nm	[otɔn]		• Je vais à Paris à l'automne. I'm going to Paris in the fall.	Je vais à Paris à l'automne.		2216. automne From Old French automne, autompne, probably later borrowed from Latin autumnus. The rural and popular term for autumn was après août (“after August”). 2282	la tache	stain, spot, mark	nf	[taʃ]		• Cette tache refuse de partir. This stain won't come out.	Cette tache refuse de partir.		2266. tache From Middle French, from Old French tache, taiche, taje (“mark, spot, stain”), from Vulgar Latin *tacca, *tecca, from Gothic 𐍄𐌰𐌹𐌺𐌽𐍃 (taikns, “mark, sign”), from Proto-Germanic *taiknaz, *taikną (“sign, mark”), from Proto-Indo-European *deik'e-, *deig'- (“to show”). Influenced by forms related to Frankish *stakjan, *stakkjan (“to stick, attach”) and Gothic 𐍃𐍄𐌰𐌺𐍃 (staks, “mark”). See attacher. For levelling and shortening of diphthong ai in taikns compare Old French hanter, hangart, etc. Cognate with Old High German zeihhan (“sign, symbol, feature”), Old English tācn (“sign, marker”). More at token.	[1]	[2]	[3]

J'ai finalement traversé le fleuve.		2353. fleuve From Middle French fleuve, from late Old French flueve (12th cent.), a dissimilated form of fluive, fluie, a reborrowing of Latin fluvius (“stream”). Replaced native Old French fluns, flum, from Latin flūmen (compare Occitan flume, Romansch flüm, Italian fiume).	[1]	[2]	[3]

In Old French sorprendre (“to overtake”) (formed from sor- (“over”); cf. modern French sur-) was distinguished from sousprendre (“to surprise, catch unaware (from beneath)”) (formed from sous- (“under”)); the two verbs later became one over time.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

2479	développer	to develop	v	[dev(ə)lɔpe]		• Développer une conscience politique prend du temps. It takes time to develop political awareness. Akin to Middle English wlappen (“to wrap, fold”) (Modern English lap 'to wrap, involve, fold'), Middle English wrappen (“to wrap”), Middle Dutch lappen (“to wrap up”), Danish dialectal vravle 'to wind, twist', Middle Low German wrempen 'to wrinkle, scrunch, distort', Old English wearp (“warp”). Je te souhaite du succès.		2584. souhaiter From Old French sohaidier, from Gallo-Roman Latin *subtus-haitare 'promise with little commitment', a hybrid of Latin subtus 'under' + Frankish *haitan (“to order, promise”), from Proto-Germanic *haitaną, compare Gothic 𐌷𐌰𐌹𐍄𐌰𐌽 (haitan, “to address, call”), Old High German heizzan, Old English hātan (“to call, order”) and Old Norse heita (“to call, name”). 3688	flotter	to float, hang, stream	v	[flɔte]					3671. flotter From Middle French, from Old French floter (“to float”), from Frankish flotōn (“to float, swim”), from Proto-Germanic *flutōną (“to float, swim”), from Proto-Indo-European *plew-, *plōw- (“to flow, swim”). 3691	la douane	customs, duty	nf	[dwan]					3674. douane Attested in 1281 in the form dohanne with the meaning 'building where the rights of entry and exit of goods are earned' (Angevin Archives of Naples). In 1441 in the form doana (“rights of entry and exit of goods”). Borrowed from Sicilian Medieval Latin doana, dovana (attested from the end of the 12th century), whence the modern Italian dogana, borrowed from the vernacular Arabic *دُوَان‎ (*duwān), an alteration of the Arabic دِيوَان‎ (dīwān), borrowed from Persian دیوان‎ (dīwān, “customs, divan”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

3752	le bourgeois	middle class	nadj(pl)	[buʀʒwa]					3735. bourgeois From Old French borgeis (“town dweller”), from borc (“fortified place, town”), from Proto-Germanic *burgz (“fortress”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰrgʰ- (“fortified elevation”). The path from Proto-Germanic to Old French is unclear. Perhaps via Frankish *burg or Late Latin *burgus, or possibly both, and probably through the Late Latin intermediate burgensis. Compare Italian borghese, Portuguese burguês, Spanish burgués.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

3785	le gain	gain	nm	[gɛ͂]					3768. gain From Middle French gain, from Old French gaaing, from the verb gaaignier (“to earn, gain, seize, conquer by force”), from Old Frankish *waidanjan (“to graze, forage, hunt”), from Proto-Germanic *waiþō (“a hunt, pasture, food”), from Proto-Indo-European *weye- (“to go, seek, crave, hunt, desire, drive”). Cognate with Old High German weidanōn (“to hunt, chase”), German Weide (“pasture, pasturage”). Compare also related Old French gain (“harvest time, revival”), from Old Frankish *waida (“income, food, fodder”) (whence French regain), from the same Germanic source.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

4139	étonner	to astonish, amaze	v	[etɔne]					4122. étonner From Middle French estonner, from Old French estoner (“to be dizzy due to a violent blow”), of obscure origin. Possibly from Old Frankish *stunōn (“to make a loud sound”), from Proto-Germanic *stunōną (“to make a sound, groan”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)ten- (“to thunder, rustle, drone, groan”). Cognate with Old English stunian (“to crash, make a loud sound”) (see stun); or from a hypothetical Latin *extonare (“to thunder out”) from ex (“out”) + tonare (“to thunder”), ultimately from the same Proto-Indo-European root; or a fusion of both. Coined 1796 by Destutt de Tracy.[1][2] Modern sense of “doctrine” attributed to use of related idéologue (“ideologue”) by Napoleon Bonaparte as a term of abuse towards political opponents in early 1800s. 4798	entraver	to hinder, hamper, get in the way of	v	[ɑ͂tʀave]					4779. entraver 1 Possibly from en- + Old French tref, or borrowed from Old Occitan entravar, from trau, from Latin trabs, trabis. From Old French enterver (“understand”) (influenced by the above word), inherited from Latin interrogāre, present active infinitive of interrogō. Doublet of interroger.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

4803	la fermeté	firmness, solidness, steadiness	nf	[fɛʀməte]					4784. fermeté Borrowed from Latin firmitās. Synchronically analysable as ferme +‎ -eté. Displaced its doublet ferté, still found in a few toponyms. See also infirmité.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

4807	advenir	to happen that, happen to	v	[advəniʀ]					4788. advenir From Middle French advenir, borrowed from Latin advenīre, present active infinitive of adveniō (or re-Latinized further from an Old French form avenir). Cf. also the archaic inherited doublet aveindre (“pull or take something from its resting place; reach or attain something through effort”), coming through a Vulgar Latin form *advenǐre or influenced by atteindre.
