DISPARAÎTRE	[Subjunctive Present]	que jeque tuqu'il, qu'elledisparaissedisparaissesdisparaisse/dis.pa.ʁɛs//dis.pa.ʁɛs//dis.pa.ʁɛs/que nousque vousqu'ils, qu'ellesdisparaissionsdisparaissiezdisparaissent/dis.pa.ʁɛ.sjɔ̃//dis.pa.ʁɛ.sje//dis.pa.ʁɛs/	disparaisse, disparaisses, disparaisse, disparaissions, disparaissiez, disparaissent	
1	de	of, from, some, any	det, prep	[də, dy, de]					1. de From Latin dē.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
2	je	I	pro	[ʒə, ʒ]					2. je From Old French jo, from Vulgar Latin *eo, from Latin ego, from Proto-Indo-European *éǵh₂. Near cognates include Spanish yo and Italian io. Further cognates include Ancient Greek ἐγώ (egṓ), Russian я (ya), English I, German ich, etc.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
3	pas	not, no	adv,nm(pl)	[pɑ]					3. pas From Latin passus. Its use as an auxiliary adverb comes from an accusative use (Latin nec... passum) in negative constructions – literally ‘not... a step’, i.e. ‘not at all’ – originally used with certain verbs of motion.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
4	le	the; him, her, it, them	det, pro	[lə]					4. le From Old French le, from Latin illum, by dropping il- and -m. Latin illum is the accusative singular of ille.[1]	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
5	que	that, which, who, whom	adv,conj,pro	[kə]					5. que 1 From Latin quia. From Latin quam. From Latin quid, from Proto-Indo-European *kʷid, compare *kʷis. From Latin quem, accusative of qui.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
6	tu	you	pro	[ty]					6. tu 1 From Old French tu, from Latin tū, from Proto-Italic *tū, from Proto-Indo-European *túh₂.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
7	vous	you(pl)	pro	[vu]					7. vous From Middle French vous, from Old French vos, vous, from Latin vōs, from Proto-Italic *wōs.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
8	un	a, an, one	adj, det, nm, pro	[œ͂]					8. un From Old French un, from Latin ūnum, accusative singular of ūnus (“one”), from Old Latin oinos, from Proto-Italic *oinos, from Proto-Indo-European *óynos.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
9	et	and	conj	[e]					9. et From Latin et (“and; plus”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
10	à	to, at, in	prep	[a]					10. à From Old French a, from Latin ad, from Proto-Indo-European *ád (“near; at”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
11	il	he, it	pro	[il]					11. il From Middle French il, from Old French il, from Vulgar Latin *illī, which is derived from Classical Latin ille.[1]	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
12	ne	not	adv	[nə]					12. ne From Latin nōn.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
13	en	in, by	adv,prep,pro	[ɑ͂]					13. en 1 From Middle French en, from Old French en, from Latin in, from Proto-Italic *en, from Proto-Indo-European *h₁én (“in”). From Latin inde (“thence”). Compare Catalan en.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
14	on	one, we	pro	[ɔ͂]					14. on From Old French hom, om (nominative form), from the homō (“human being”) (compare homme from the Old French oblique form home, from the Latin accusative form hominem). Its pronominal use is of Germanic origin. Compare Old English man (“one, they, people”), reduced form of Old English mann (“man, person”); Catalan hom; German man (“one, they, people”); Dutch men (“one, they, people”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
15	ce	this, that	det,pro	[sə]					15. ce 1 From Old French cel, from earlier cil, from Vulgar Latin *ecce illu, from Latin ecce or eccum illum, from ille. Probably from Latin ecce hoc.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
16	pour	for, in order to	prep	[puʀ]					16. pour From Old French por, from Latin pro.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
17	qui	who, whom	pro	[ki]					17. qui From Middle French qui, from Old French qui, from Latin quī, from Old Latin quei, from Proto-Italic *kʷoi, from Proto-Indo-European *kʷos, *kʷis.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
18	mais	but	adv,conj,intj	[mɛ]					18. mais From Old French mes, mais, from Latin magis.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
19	dans	in, into, from	prep	[dɑ͂]					19. dans 1 From Vulgar Latin de intus or deintus, meaning 'from inside' or 'from within'. See dan.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
20	nous	we, us	pro	[nu]					20. nous 1 From Middle French nous, from Old French nous, nos, from Latin nōs, from Proto-Italic *nōs. From Ancient Greek νοῦς (noûs) or νόος (nóos, “mind”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
21	elle	she, her	pro	[ɛl]					21. elle 1 From Old French ele, from Latin illa, feminine of ille.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
22	bien	well	adji,adv,nm	[bjɛ͂]					22. bien From Middle French bien, from Old French bien, from Latin bene (“well”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
24	me	me, to me, myself	pro	[mə]					24. me From Middle French me, from Old French me, from Latin mē (accusative of ego), from Proto-Indo-European *(e)me-, *(e)me-n- (“me”). Northern dialects have preserved a form mi for the indirect object (also found in Old French in the Oaths of Strasbourg), from Latin mihi, dative singular of ego, through a Vulgar Latin *mi, whereas in standard French, it has merged into me.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
25	si	if, whether	adv,conj,nmi	[si]					25. si 1 From Old French se, from Latin si (“if”). From Old French si, from Latin sic (“so, thus”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
26	y	there	adv,nmi,pro	[igʀɛk]					26. y 1 From i grec (“Greek i”), referring to the letter upsilon (Υ), originally borrowed from the Greek alphabet, as opposed to 'Latin i' (I). 10th century; from Old French i, from Latin hīc (“here”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *ǵʰi-ḱe (“this, here”)), with meaning influenced by Old French iv (“there, thither”), itself from Latin ibī. Derivation from the latter poses difficulty from a phonetic standpoint. Eye dialect spelling of il. or Contraction of il. .	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
27	non	no, not	adv,nmi	[nɔ͂]					27. non From Old French non, from Latin nōn.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
28	avec	with	prep	[avɛk]					28. avec From Middle French avec, avecques (“with”), from Old French avoc, avoec, avuec (“with”), from an assumed Vulgar Latin *aboc, *abhoc, *apud hŏque[1][2], a Frankish alteration consisting of Latin apud (“with, near, close to”) with hoc (“this”) and -que. First used as a replacement for Latin cum (“with”) in Merovingian and Carolingian (Frankish) documents. Gradually supplanted Old French od (“with”), itself from apud.[2] Cognate with Picard aveuc, Norman aveu, Walloon avou and Franco-Provençal: avouéc.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
29	tout	all, very	adv,det,nadj,pro	[tu]					29. tout From Middle French tout, from Old French tot, from Latin tōtus; compare Catalan tot, Italian tutto, Portuguese todo, Romanian tot, Spanish todo.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
30	plus	more, no more	adv	[ply]					30. plus 1 From Old French plus, from Latin plus, from Old Latin *plous, from Proto-Indo-European *pleh₁-, *pelh₁u- (“many”). Inflected forms.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
31	mon	my	det	[mɔ͂, me]					31. mon From Middle French mon, from Old French mun, from Vulgar Latin, Late Latin mum, a reduced variant of Latin meum, nominative neuter singular of meus.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
32	te	you, to you, from you	pro	[tə]					32. te From Middle French te, from Old French te, from Latin tē, (accusative of tū), from Proto-Indo-European *twé, *te, accusative of *túh₂ (“you”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
33	fait	done, fact	adj,nm	[fɛ]					33. fait From Middle French fait, from Old French fet, from Latin factum.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
34	moi	me	nm,pro	[mwa]					34. moi From Middle French moy, from Old French mei, moi, mi (“me”), tonic form of me, from Latin mē (“me”), from Proto-Indo-European *(e)me-, *(e)me-n- (“me”). More at me.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
35	oui	yes	adv,nmi	[ˊwi]					35. oui [1380]; from Old French oïl (1100), compound of o affirmative particle (compare Occitan òc ‘yes’) and il ‘he, him’, akin to o-je, o-tu, o nos, o vos, all ‘yes’ constructed with pronouns.[1] O and òc are both from Latin hoc ‘this’. Compare Portuguese isso ‘yes, yeah’, literally ‘this, that’. And the semantic shift is calqued on Gaulish: Compare fellow Celtic languages such as Old Irish tó ‘yes’, Welsh do ‘indeed’, from Proto-Indo-European *tod (“this, that”).[2]	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
36	faire	to do, make	nm,v	[fɛʀ]					36. faire From Middle French faire, from Old French faire, feire, fere, from Latin facere, present active infinitive of faciō, from Proto-Italic *fakiō, from Proto-Indo-European *dʰeh₁- (“to put, place, set”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
37	sur	on, upon	adj,prep	[syʀ]					37. sur 1 From Middle French sur, from Old French sur, seur, sor, soure, souvre, sovre (“on, upon, over”), from Latin super (“over, on, above”), from *eks-uper, from *h₁eǵʰs (“out of”) (Latin ex) and *uperi (“above”), from *upo. Doublet of super, a borrowing. Cognate with Old English ofer (“over, above”). More at over. From Middle French sur, from Old French sur (“sour, bitter”), from Frankish *sūr (“acidic, sour”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
38	quoi	what	pro	[kwa]					38. quoi From Latin quid; ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *kʷid, compare *kʷis. Cognate to English what, which differs due to changing under Grimm’s law.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
39	se	oneself, himself, herself, itself, themselves	pro	[sə]					39. se From Middle French se, from Old French se, from Latin sē, from Proto-Indo-European *swé (reflexive pronoun). See also soi.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
40	comme	like, as	adv,conj	[kɔm]					40. comme From Middle French comme, from Old French cum, com, conme, from Vulgar Latin *quomo, from Latin quōmodo.[1] Later the conjunction et was added to com, resulting in comme.[2] Cognate to Italian come. See also Spanish como and Catalan com.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
41	être	to be; being	nm,v	[ɛtʀ]					41. être From Middle French estre, from a merger of two verbs:	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
42	ici	here	adv	[isi]		• Je suis ici. I am here. • Qui était ici? Who was here ?	Je suis ici. Qui était ici?		42. ici From an i taken from an Old French iluec (from Latin illoc) + ci, itself from Latin ecce hīc.	[1]	[2]	[3]
43	toi	you, yourself	nm,pro	[twa]		• Je suis avec toi. I'm by your side. • Bien fait pour toi. That serves you right.	Je suis avec toi. Bien fait pour toi.		43. toi From Middle French toi, tei, from Old French tei, te, from Latin tē.	[1]	[2]	[3]
44	dit	said, so-called; tale	nadj	[di, dit]					44. dit From Old French dit, from Latin dictus.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
45	lui	him, her	pro	[lɥi]		• Elle est tout pour lui. She is everything to him. • Je lui ai dit quoi faire. I told him what to do.	Elle est tout pour lui. Je lui ai dit quoi faire.		45. lui 1 From Vulgar Latin *illūi, which is a Vulgar Latin form of Latin illī (dative singular of ille). The -ui ending in Vulgar Latin illui is due to the influence of cui.[1] see the verb luire	[1]	[2]	[3]
46	votre	your	det	[vɔtʀ]					46. votre From Middle French vostre, from Old French vostre, from Latin voster, vostrum, vostra(m), from earlier vester, from Proto-Italic *westeros.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
47	pourquoi	why	adv,conj,nmi	[puʀkwa]					47. pourquoi From Middle French parquoy, from Old French por quoi.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
48	où	where	adv,pro	[u]		• Je sais où elle est. I know where she is.	Je sais où elle est.		48. où From Middle French où, from Old French ou, from Latin ubi (“where?”). The grave accent was added in Middle French to differentiate from ou (“or”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
49	rien	nothing	adv,nm,pro	[ʀjɛ͂]		• Je ne sais rien de lui. I don't know anything about him.	Je ne sais rien de lui.		49. rien From Old French rien, from Latin rem, accusative of rēs (“thing”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
50	là	there, here	adv,intj	[la]		• Il est là. There it is. • Qui va là? Who goes there ? • Tout est là. It's all there.	Il est là. Qui va là? Tout est là.		50. là From Middle French la, from Old French la, from Latin illac. The grave accent on the a was added to disambiguate with la (“the”). Compare Spanish allá, Portuguese lá.	[1]	[2]	[3]
51	quand	when	adv,conj	[kɑ͂]					51. quand From Middle French quand, quant, from Old French quant, qant, from Latin quandō.[1]	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
52	dire	to say	nm,v	[diʀ]		• Je veux vous le dire. I want to tell you. • Dites toujours la vérité. Always tell the truth. • Tous mes amis disent ça. All my friends say that.	Je veux vous le dire. Dites toujours la vérité. Tous mes amis disent ça.		52. dire From Middle French dire, from Old French dire, from Latin dīcere, present active infinitive of dīcō, from Proto-Italic *deikō, from Proto-Indo-European *déyḱti (“to show, point out”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
53	son	his, her, its; sound	det,nm	[sɔ͂]					53. son 1 From Old French son, suen, suon, from Latin sonus (the current form may be remade after or influenced by sonner). From Middle French son, from Old French son, from Vulgar Latin sum, a reduced/atonic variant of suus, suum, from Proto-Italic *sowos, from Proto-Indo-European *sewos, from *swé (“self”). From Latin secundus (presumably through an earlier Old French form *seon; cf. an attested Medieval Latin seonno, seonnum). Cognate with Catalan segó, Old Occitan segon. The meaning derives from the fact that bran results from a second sifting of flour. Doublet of second, a borrowing.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
54	ton	your	det,nm	[tɔ͂]					54. ton 1 From Old French ton, tos, from Latin tuus, from Proto-Indo-European *towos. Borrowed from Latin tonus. Doublet of tonus, a later borrowing.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
55	alors	then, so	adv	[alɔʀ]					55. alors From Old French a +‎ lors.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
56	comment	how	adv,conj,intj,nmi	[kɔmɑ͂]		• Comment ça va? How are you ?	Comment ça va?		56. comment comme +‎ -ment[1]	[1]	[2]	[3]
57	par	by	prep	[paʀ]					57. par From Middle French par, from Old French par, from Latin per, from Proto-Indo-European *peri.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
58	ou	or	conj	[u]					58. ou From Old French ou, from Latin aut.[1]	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
59	la chose	thing	adj(f),nf	[ʃoz]					59. chose From Old French chose, from Latin causa. Compare Italian cosa, Portuguese coisa, Spanish cosa among many others. Compare cause, a borrowed doublet.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
60	bon	good	adj,adv,intj,nm	[bɔ͂]		• Je suis bon. I am good. • Vous êtes vraiment bons. You really are good. • Nous sommes bons amis. We are good friends. • Vous êtes bons. You are good.	Je suis bon. Vous êtes vraiment bons. Nous sommes bons amis. Vous êtes bons.		60. bon From Middle French bon, from Old French bon, from Latin bonus (“good”), from Old Latin duenos, later duonus, from Proto-Italic *dwenos, from Proto-Indo-European *dew- (“to show favor, revere”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
61	le merci, la merci	thank you; favor	intj,nm,nf	[mɛʀsi]					61. merci From Middle French merci, mercy, from Old French merci, from Latin mercēdem, accusative singular of mercēs (“wages, fee, price”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
62	juste	just, only; fair	adv,nadj(f)	[ʒyst]					62. juste From Old French juste, in this form probably borrowed from Latin iūstus, jūstus, from Proto-Italic *jowestos, from Proto-Indo-European *h₂yew-. The Old French form just may have been inherited, however, and perhaps later modified based on the Latin.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
63	très	very	adv	[tʀɛ]		• Je vais très bien. I feel very good.	Je vais très bien.		63. très From Old French trés, inherited from Latin trans. Doublet of trans-.	[1]	[2]	[3]
64	jamais	never	adv	[ʒamɛ]					64. jamais From Old French ja més, jamés (“ever”), from Latin iam magis (“yet more”). Compare Spanish jamás, Italian giammai and Portuguese jamais.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
65	un été	"summer; past particle of être (""to be"")"	nm	[ete]					65. été 1 From Old French esté, from Latin aestās, aestātem, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *h₂eydʰ- (“burn; fire”). From Latin stātus, past participle of stō (which was conflated with sum in Old French). Compare also the noun état.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
66	avoir	to have	nm,v	[avwaʀ]					66. avoir From Middle French avoir, from Old French avoir, aveir, aver, from Vulgar Latin *avēre, from Latin habēre, present active infinitive of habeō (“have, hold, possess”), probably from a Proto-Italic *habēō or *haβēō, possibly ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *gʰh₁bʰ- (“to grab, to take”). Influenced and reinforced by similar (yet etymologically unrelated) verbs in Germanic; compare Frankish *habēn, *hebōn (“to have”), Gothic 𐌷𐌰𐌱𐌰𐌽 (haban, “to have”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
67	vraiment	truly, really, very	adv	[vʀɛmɑ͂]		• Tu es vraiment bon. You really are good.	Tu es vraiment bon.		67. vraiment From Middle French vrayement, from Old French veraiement, equivalent to vrai +‎ -ment. Compare Italian veramente.	[1]	[2]	[3]
68	aussi	too, also, as	adv,conj	[osi]		• Tu peux le faire, aussi. You can do it, too.	Tu peux le faire, aussi.		68. aussi From Old French ausi, from Latin aliud sic (“another thing thus”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
69	voir	to see	v	[vwaʀ]					69. voir From Old French veoir, veir, from earlier vedeir, from Latin vidēre, present active infinitive of videō, from Proto-Italic *widēō, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *weyd-.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
70	oh	oh	intj	[o]						[ ]	[ ]	[ ]
71	même	same, even, self	adj(f),adv,pro	[mɛm]					71. même From Middle French mesme, from Old French mesme, earlier meïsme, from Vulgar Latin *metipsimus, from Latin -met + ipse + -issimus. Cognates include Bourguignon moîme, Spanish mismo, Portuguese mesmo and Italian medesimo.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
72	maintenant	now	adv	[mɛ͂t(ə)nɑ͂]		• Je vais bien maintenant. I'm feeling fine now. • Si pas maintenant, alors quand? If not now, then when ? • Tout va bien maintenant. Everything's all right now. • Si pas maintenant, quand? If not now, when ?	Je vais bien maintenant. Si pas maintenant, alors quand? Tout va bien maintenant. Si pas maintenant, quand?		72. maintenant From maintenir +‎ -ant. Equivalent to main +‎ tenant.	[1]	[2]	[3]
73	le deux	two	det,nmi	[dø]					73. deux From Middle French deux, from Old French deus, from Latin duōs, masculine accusative of duo, from Proto-Italic *duō, from Proto-Indo-European *dwóh₁.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
74	autre	other	det,nadj(f),pro	[otʀ]		• Autre chose? Anything else ? • Où sont les autres? Where are the others ?	Autre chose? Où sont les autres?		74. autre From Old French altre, autre, from Latin alter, alterum, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *h₂élteros.	[1]	[2]	[3]
75	peu	little	adv	[pø]					75. peu From Old French poi, from Latin paucus, from Proto-Italic *paukus, ultimately from the Proto-Indo-European *peh₂w- (“few”, “little”). Compare Catalan poc, Italian poco, Portuguese Portuguese pouco, Spanish Spanish poco.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
76	quelque	some	adv,adj,det	[kɛlk]					76. quelque quel +‎ que	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
77	le temps	time	nm(pl)	[tɑ͂]		• Il est temps. It's about time. • Je le fais tout le temps. I do that all the time. • Comment est le temps? How is the weather ? • Il y a un temps pour tout. There is a right time for everything. • Il fait ça tout le temps. He does this all the time.	Il est temps. Je le fais tout le temps. Comment est le temps? Il y a un temps pour tout. Il fait ça tout le temps.		77. temps From Old French temps and its variants, from Latin tempus, from Proto-Indo-European *tempos (“stretch”), from the root *temp- (“to stretch, string”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
78	toujours	always	adv	[tuʒuʀ]		• Il est toujours avec moi. He is always with me. • Je le fais toujours. I still do that. • Je fais toujours la même chose. I always do the same thing.	Il est toujours avec moi. Je le fais toujours. Je fais toujours la même chose.		78. toujours From Middle French tousjours, from Old French toz jorz, tuzjurz (“without ceasing”, literally “all days”), equivalent to tous +‎ jours (compare Dutch altijd (“always”), Danish altid (“always”)). Replaced Old French sempres (“always”), from Latin semper.	[1]	[2]	[3]
79	encore	again, yet	adv	[ɑ͂kɔʀ]		• Il est encore ici. He is still here. • Encore merci pour tout. Thanks again for everything. • Je le fais encore. I still do that. • Je fais encore ça de temps en temps. I still do that from time to time.	Il est encore ici. Encore merci pour tout. Je le fais encore. Je fais encore ça de temps en temps.		79. encore Probably from Late Latin in hanc hōram (“until this hour”). Compare Occitan encara, Italian ancora.	[1]	[2]	[3]
80	notre	our	det	[nɔtʀ, no]					80. notre From Old French nostre, Latin noster, nostrum, nostra(m), from Proto-Italic *nosteros.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
81	besoin	need	nm	[bəzwɛ͂]					81. besoin From Middle French, Old French besoing; can be seen as a masculine variant of besogne, from Old French besonge, from Old Frankish *bisunnija, from *sunnijōn (“to look after”) (whence soigner), possibly through a Vulgar Latin intermediate *bisonium. Compare Italian bisogno.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
82	un accord	agreement	nm	[akɔʀ]					82. accord Deverbal of accorder.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
83	la vie	life	nf	[vi]		• Je vous dois la vie. I owe you my life. • Je lui dois la vie. I owe him my life.	Je vous dois la vie. Je lui dois la vie.		83. vie 1 From Old French vie, from Latin vīta, from Proto-Italic *gʷītā. Ultimately from Latin via. Compare voie.	[1]	[2]	[3]
84	aller	to go	nm,v	[ale]		• Je vais bien. I am fine. • Tu peux y aller. You can go there. • Vous allez bien. You're all right. • Allons le dire aux autres. Let's go tell the others. • Tout allait très bien. Everything was going great.	Je vais bien. Tu peux y aller. Vous allez bien. Allons le dire aux autres. Tout allait très bien.		84. aller A suppletive verb; Latin vādō (“go”) supplies the present tense forms and īre, present active infinitive of eō, supplies the future and conditional.	[1]	[2]	[3]
85	la fois	time, times	nf(pl)	[fwa]					85. fois 1 From Middle French foys, from Old French foiz, feiz, from Latin vices, plural of the noun vicis. Inflected form	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
86	sans	without	prep	[sɑ͂]					86. sans From Old French sans, senz, sens, from Latin sine conflated with absentia in the sense 'without'. Cognates include Spanish sin, Portuguese sem, Italian senza, Catalan sens, sense.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
87	donc	so, then, therefore, thus	conj	[dɔ͂k]					87. donc From Middle French donc, variant of doncques, from Old French donkes (“then”). Of uncertain and disputed origin. Perhaps an apheresis of adonc, from Latin ad-tunc, or a blend of Latin dum (“while”) + tum, tunc (“then”). Compare also Italian dunque.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
88	le monde	world, people	nm	[mɔ͂d]					88. monde 1 From Latin mundus (“world”). From Latin mundus (“pure; clean”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
89	avant	before; forward	adji,adv,nm,prep	[avɑ͂]					89. avant From Middle French, from Old French avant (“before, prior in time, forward”), from Late Latin abante (“before, in front of”) (compare Classical Latin ante (“before, in front of”)), from Latin ab (“of, from”) + ante (“before”). More at ante.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
90	sûr	sure	adj	[syʀ]		• Je suis sûr. I am sure. • Nous pouvons être sûrs de cela. We can be certain of that. • Je suis sûre de pouvoir le faire. I'm sure that I can do that.	Je suis sûr. Nous pouvons être sûrs de cela. Je suis sûre de pouvoir le faire.		90. sûr From Old French seür, inherited from Latin sēcūrus.	[1]	[2]	[3]
91	trop	too much, too many	adv	[tʀo]					91. trop From Middle French trop, from Old French trop (“unreasonably excessive”), from Frankish *thorp (“a cluster, agglomeration', also 'collection of houses, village”), from Proto-Germanic *þurpą (“village”), from Proto-Indo-European *trab-, *treb- (“dwelling, room”). Cognate with Old Saxon thorp (“village”), Old High German thorf (“village”), Old English þorp (“village”). More at thorp, troop.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
92	parler	to speak	nm,v	[paʀle]		• Je dois parler avec toi. I must talk with you. • Il parle vraiment bien. He speaks really well. • Ne lui en parle pas. Don't tell her about it. • Parle avec moi. Talk to me.	Je dois parler avec toi. Il parle vraiment bien. Ne lui en parle pas. Parle avec moi.		92. parler From Middle French parler (“to speak or talk”), from Old French parler (“to talk; to speak”), from Vulgar Latin *paraulare (“to speak”), from Late Latin parabolare, from Latin parabola (“comparison”), from Ancient Greek παραβολή (parabolḗ), from παραβάλλω (parabállō, “to compare”), from παρά (pará, “beside”) + βάλλω (bállō, “to throw”).	[1]	[2]	[3]

94	la personne	person, people, anybody, anyone, nobody	nf,pro	[pɛʀsɔn]		• Personne ne peut faire ça. No one can do that. • Cette personne est comme moi. That person is like me. • Personne ne dit rien. No one said anything. • Personne ne dit plus ça. No one says that anymore.	Personne ne peut faire ça. Cette personne est comme moi. Personne ne dit rien. Personne ne dit plus ça.		94. personne From Latin persona.	[1]	[2]	[3]

98	un homme	man	nm	[ɔm]		• Je suis un homme. I am a man.	Je suis un homme.		98. homme From Middle French homme, from Old French home, hom, hume, homme, etc, from Latin homō, hominem (with the loss of the -in- syllable), from Old Latin hemō, from Proto-Italic *hemō, from Proto-Indo-European *ǵʰmṓ (“earthling”). Compare Catalan home, Italian uomo, Portuguese homem, Romanian om, Sardinian ómine, Neapolitan hommo, Spanish hombre. Compare also French on, derived from the nominative of Latin homō.	[1]	[2]	[3]
99	la femme	woman, wife	nf	[fam]		• Comment va ta femme? How's your wife doing ? • Ta femme est ici. Your wife is here. • Je connais ces femmes. I know those women.	Comment va ta femme? Ta femme est ici. Je connais ces femmes.		99. femme From Middle French femme, from Old French fame, femme, feme, from Latin fēmina, from Proto-Indo-European *dʰeh₁-m̥h₁n-éh₂ (“(the one) nursing, breastfeeding”), derivation of the verbal root *dʰeh₁(y)- (“to suck, suckle”). Various spellings such as feme, fame and fenme were used in Old French.	[1]	[2]	[3]
100	leur	them, their, theirs	det,adj(f),pro	[lœʀ]					100. leur From Old French lor, from Latin illōrum, genitive masculine plural of ille.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
101	vrai	true	adv,nadj	[vʀɛ]		• Tout est vrai. It's all true. • Ça peut bien être vrai. It may well be true. • Son histoire semble vraie. His story sounds true. • Toutes ces choses sont vraies. All these things are true.	Tout est vrai. Ça peut bien être vrai. Son histoire semble vraie. Toutes ces choses sont vraies.		101. vrai From Old French verai, from the Vulgar Latin *vērācus, from Latin vērāx, from vērus (“true, real”), from Proto-Italic *wēros, from a Proto-Indo-European *weh₁-ros, from *weh₁- (“true”). 102	mal	bad	adji,adv,nm	[mal]		• Personne ne va te faire de mal. No one is going to harm you.	Personne ne va te faire de mal.		102. mal 1 From Old French mal, from Latin malus, possibly derived from Proto-Indo-European *mel- (“bad, wrong”). Near cognates include Portuguese mal, Portuguese male and Spanish malo. From Old French, from Latin male.	[1]	[2]	[3]
103	chez	at, with; home	prep, n	[ʃe]		• Je dois aller chez moi. I need to go home. • Je veux aller chez moi maintenant. I want to go home now.	Je dois aller chez moi. Je veux aller chez moi maintenant.		103. chez From Old French chiese, chese, from Latin casa (“house”). Doublet of case.	[1]	[2]	[3]

106	beaucoup	a lot of, many	adv	[boku]		• Je veux beaucoup plus. I want much more. • Il y a encore beaucoup à faire. There's still a lot to be done.	Je veux beaucoup plus. Il y a encore beaucoup à faire.		106. beaucoup From Old French biau cop, first attested circa 1210.[1] Equivalent to beau (“nice, beautiful”) +‎ coup (“hit, strike”). The latter word also means “helping of soup or beverage”, first attested circa 1375, which sense may have triggered or reinforced beaucoup to mean “a lot”.	[1]	[2]	[3]
107	le mort, la mort	dead; death	adj,nf	[mɔʀ]					107. mort 1 From Middle French, from Old French mort, from Vulgar Latin *mortu, from Latin mortuus, from Proto-Indo-European *mr̥twós, *mr̥tós. 109	la mère	mother	adj,nf	[mɛʀ]		• Qui est votre mère? Who is your mother ? • Mon père aime ma mère. My father loves my mother. • Comment va votre mère? How is your mother ?	Qui est votre mère? 110	la fille	girl, daughter	nf	[fij]		• Tu es ma fille. You are my daughter. • Il avait une fille. He had one daughter. • Comment va ta fille? How is your daughter ? • Je connais ces filles. I know those girls. • Où sont les autres filles? Where are the other girls ?	Tu es ma fille. Il avait une fille. Comment va ta fille? Je connais ces filles. Où sont les autres filles?		110. fille (daughter): From Middle French fille, from Old French fille, from Latin fīlia. (slang, prostitute): By ellipsis of the euphemisms fille des rues (“girl of the streets”), fille de joie (“girl of joy”), fille publique (“public girl”), and others like them that signify 'prostitute'. Pronunciation IPA(key): /fij/ (Quebec) IPA(key): [fɪj] Noun fille f (plural filles)	[1]	[2]	[3]
111	le gens	people	nmpl	[ʒɑ͂]		• Qui sont ces gens? Who are these people ?	Qui sont ces gens?		111. gens From an earlier gents, from the plural of Old French gent, genz, from from Latin gentis or gentem, forms of gēns, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *ǵénh₁tis.	[1]	[2]	[3]
112	quel	which, what	det,adj,pro	[kɛl]					112. quel From Middle French quel, from Old French quel, from Latin quālis, quālem.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
113	voilà	right, there, here	prep	[vwala]		• Nous y voilà! Here we are !	Nous y voilà!		113. voilà From vois (“see!, look!”), second-person singular imperative of voir (“to see, to look”) and là (“there”), literally meaning 'look there!'.	[1]	[2]	[3]
114	le petit	small, little	nadj	[p(ə)ti, it]		• Le monde est petit. It's a small world. • Cette maison est très petite. That house is very small. • Elle a une petite maison. She has a small house. • Ma famille est petite. My family is small. • Ma maison est petite. My house is small.	Le monde est petit. Cette maison est très petite. Elle a une petite maison. Ma famille est petite. Ma maison est petite.		114. petit From Old French petit, from Vulgar Latin pittitus (775; compare Latin pitinnus, pitulus), possibly from Celtic or Frankish.	[1]	[2]	[3]
115	la maison	house	nf	[mɛzɔ͂]		• Je suis dans la maison. I am in the house. • Cette maison est à moi. That house belongs to me. • Ma maison est ta maison. My home is your home. • Je veux faire ça à la maison. I want to do this at home. • Ces maisons sont grandes. Those houses are big.	Je suis dans la maison. Cette maison est à moi. Ma maison est ta maison. Je veux faire ça à la maison. Ces maisons sont grandes.		115. maison From Middle French, from Old French maisun, meson, inherited from Latin mansiō, mansiōnem (“abode, home, dwelling”), from maneō (“remain, stay”) (whence also French manoir). 116	soit	either...or	adv,conj	[swat]						[ ]	[ ]	[ ]

118	cela	that, it	pro	[s(ə)la]		• Cela peut être vrai. It may be true. • Je ne crois plus cela. I no longer believe that. • Tu dis toujours cela. You're always saying that. • Merci à tous pour cela. Thank you all for that.	Cela peut être vrai. Je ne crois plus cela. Tu dis toujours cela. Merci à tous pour cela.		118. cela Equivalent to ce +‎ là. See also -là.	[1]	[2]	[3]
119	le passé	past	nadj,prep	[pɑse]		• Je ne sais rien de son passé. I don't know anything about his past.	Je ne sais rien de son passé.			[1]	[2]	[ ]
120	le jour	day	nm	[ʒuʀ]		• Elle va mieux de jour en jour. She is getting better day by day.	Elle va mieux de jour en jour.		120. jour From Old French jor, jorn, from Latin diurnum [tempus], from the neuter of the adjective diurnus (“of the day”), which is cognate with diēs (“day”). Doublet of diurne, a borrowing.	[1]	[2]	[3]
121	prendre	to take	v	[pʀɑ͂dʀ]		• Tu peux prendre ton temps. You can take your time. • Je prendrai du gâteau. I'll have some cake. • La maison prit feu. The house caught fire. • Prends ça. Take this.	Tu peux prendre ton temps. Je prendrai du gâteau. La maison prit feu. Prends ça.		121. prendre From Middle French prendre, from Old French prendre, prandre, from Latin prendere, alternative form of prehendere (“to seize”), present active infinitive of prehendō, from prae- (“before”) + *hendō (“I take, seize”) (not attested without prefix), from Proto-Indo-European *gʰed-; confer English apprehend.	[1]	[2]	[3]
122	le monsieur	mister, sir, gentleman	nm	[məsjø, mesjø]					122. monsieur From mon (“my”) + sieur, from the oblique case of Old French sire (cf. also seignor), ultimately from Latin senior.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
123	savoir	to know	nm,v	[savwaʀ]					123. savoir From Old French savoir, saveir, from Vulgar Latin *sapēre, from Latin sapĕre (“to taste”) (and 'to know' in Late Latin, by influence of the adjective sapiēns (“wise”)), present active infinitive of sapiō. Ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *seh₁p- (“to try, to research”). The verb was for a long time spelled sçavoir from Middle French until the 18th century, by false regression to Classical Latin scīre 'to know'.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
124	un argent	money; silver	nm	[aʀʒɑ͂]		• Je lui dois quelque argent. I owe him some money.	Je lui dois quelque argent.		124. argent From Middle French argent, from Old French argent, from Latin argentum (according to the TLFi etymological dictionary, a borrowing), itself from Proto-Italic *argentom, from Proto-Indo-European *h₂r̥ǵn̥tóm, from *h₂erǵ- (“white”).	[1]	[2]	[3]

140	le problème	problem	nm	[pʀɔblɛm]		• Sans problème. No problem. • Ils ont un problème. They have a problem. • Quel est votre problème? What is your problem ? • Tu as eu des problèmes? Tu as eu des problèmes?		140. problème Borrowed from Latin problēma, from Ancient Greek πρόβλημα (próblēma, “obstacle”), from προβάλλω (probállō, “to throw or lay something in front of someone, to put forward”), from προ- (pro-, “in front of”) + βάλλω (bállō, “to throw, to cast, to hurl”). 149	le travail	work	nm	[tʀavaj, o]		• Tu as un bon travail. You have a good job. • Je vais au travail. I go to work. • Mon travail est fait. My work is done. • Il y a beaucoup de travail à faire. 173	le sens	sense, meaning	nm(pl)	[sɑ͂s]		• Cela fait vraiment sens. That really made sense.	Cela fait vraiment sens.		"173. sens 1 From Middle French, from Old French sens, sen, san (“sense, reason, direction”), partly from Latin sensus (“sense, sensation, feeling, meaning”), from sentiō (“feel, perceive”); partly from Frankish *sinn (“sense, reason, mental faculty, way, direction”), from Proto-Germanic *sinnaz (“mind, meaning”). Both Latin and Germanic from Proto-Indo-European *sent- (“to feel”). Compare also French assener (“to thrust out”), forcené (“maniac”). More at send. <="""" span=""""> From sentir."	[1]	[2]	[3]

194	un aide, une aide	help, assistance	nm,nf	[ɛd]		• Ça aide un peu. That helps a bit. • Qui aide ta mère? Who helps your mother ? • Elle nous aide. She helps us. • Ça aide. Merci pour ton aide.		194. aide From the verb aider, with the third-person singular form corresponding to Latin adiūtat.	[1]	[2]	[3]

196	le genre	type, kind, sort	nm	[ʒɑ͂ʀ]		• Je connais votre genre. I know your type. • Ce genre de choses arrive tout le temps. 198	le frère	brother	nm	[fʀɛʀ]		• Qui est ton frère? Who is your brother ? • Mon frère parle très vite. My brother speaks very fast. • Je connais votre frère. I know your brother. • Il a trois frères. He has three brothers. • Nous sommes frères. We are brothers.	Qui est ton frère? Mon frère parle très vite. Je connais votre frère. Il a trois frères. Nous sommes frères.		198. frère From Old French frere, from older fredre, fradre, from Latin frāter, frātrem, from Proto-Italic *frātēr, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *bʰréh₂tēr.	[1]	[2]	[3]
199	laisser	to leave, to let	v	[lese]					199. laisser From Middle French laisser, from Old French lesser, lessier, laissier (“to let, let go, leave”), from Latin laxō (“to relax, loosen”); partly from or influenced by Old High German lāzan (“to let, let go, leave”) (German lassen), from Proto-Germanic *lētaną (“to let, leave, leave alone”), from Proto-Indo-European *leh₁d- (“to leave, let”). Cognate with Old English lǣtan (“to allow, let go, leave, rent”), Gothic 𐌻𐌴𐍄𐌰𐌽 (lētan, “to release, forgive”). Conflated also with Old French laiier (“to leave, abandon, allow”) (compare Old Occitan laihar, laiar, Old Northern Italian lagare), also of Germanic origin, from Gothic 𐌻𐌰𐌲𐌾𐌰𐌽 (lagjan, “to lay, let lie, leave”), from Proto-Germanic *lagjaną (“to lay”). More at let, lay.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

205	chaque	each	det,adj	[ʃak]		• Je viens ici chaque jour. I come here every day. Old French chascun derives from a Vulgar Latin *cascunum, from a crossing of quisque unus with catunum < cata unum. 228	pouvoir	can, to be able to	nm,v	[puvwaʀ]					228. pouvoir From Middle French povoir, from Old French povoir, pooir, from early Old French poeir, from Vulgar Latin *potēre (“to be able”), *possō for Classical Latin posse, present active infinitive of possum. The Latin infinitive *potēre was a regularized form from the root potis (“able”) or formed on the basis of the present participle potens. The v is an epenthetic consonant added to avoid hiatus. 269	appeler	to call	v	[aple]		• Tu devrais appeler la police. You should call the police. • Vous pouvez nous appeler à tout moment. You can call us at any time. • Ne m'appelez plus. Don't call me anymore. • Comment tu t'appelles? What is your name ? • Je l'ai appelée. I called her up.	Tu devrais appeler la police. Vous pouvez nous appeler à tout moment. Ne m'appelez plus. Comment tu t'appelles? Je l'ai appelée.		269. appeler From Latin appellāre, present active infinitive of appellō (“to address, to call by name”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
270	la semaine	week	nf	[s(ə)mɛn]		• Je peux le faire en une semaine. I can do it in a week. • Ma famille sera au loin pour une semaine. My family will be away for a week. • Tu as trois semaines. You've got three weeks. • Trois semaines ont passé. Three weeks went by.	Je peux le faire en une semaine. Ma famille sera au loin pour une semaine. Tu as trois semaines. Trois semaines ont passé.		270. semaine From Old French semaine, from Late Latin septimāna (“week”), from the Latin septimānus (“related to the seventh element of a series”, adjective), derived from septimus (“seventh”). 291	la guerre	war	nf	[gɛʀ]		• Ils vont à la guerre. They're going to the war. • Nous avons connu trois guerres. We have seen three wars.	Ils vont à la guerre. Nous avons connu trois guerres.		291. guerre From Middle French guerre (“war”) from Old French guerre, guere (“armed conflict between individuals or states, enmity, strife between individuals”) (compare Old Northern French werre) from Late Latin *werra, *guerra, from Frankish *werra (“riot, disturbance, quarrel”) from Proto-Germanic *werrō (“confusion, disarray”), from Proto-Indo-European *wers- (“to mix up, confuse, beat, thresh”). Akin to English war, Old High German werra (“confusion, strife, quarrel”) (German verwirren (“to confuse”)), Old Saxon werran (“to confuse, perplex”), Dutch war (“confusion, disarray”), Old English wyrsa, wiersa (“worse”). More at worse, wurst.	[1]	[2]	[3]

Je pense souvent à toi.		421. souvent From Old French suvent, sovent, from Latin subinde, which consists of sub + inde. 459	tirer	to pull, fire	v	[tiʀe]					455. tirer From Middle French tirer (“to draw, draw a sword”), from Old French tirer (“to draw, pull out with great effort, snatch violently, tear away”), from Medieval Latin, from Vulgar Latin *tīrō, tīrāre, of uncertain origin, but probably Germanic; possibly from Gothic *𐍄𐌹𐍂𐌰𐌽 (*tiran, “to tear away, remove”), from Proto-Germanic *teraną (“to tear, tear apart”), from Proto-Indo-European *der- (“to tear, tear apart”). Compare Italian tirare, Catalan, Portuguese, and Spanish tirar. If derived from the Germanic word, cognate with Gothic 𐌳𐌹𐍃𐍄𐌰𐌹𐍂𐌰𐌽 (distairan, “to tear apart”), Gothic 𐌲𐌰𐍄𐌰𐌹𐍂𐌰𐌽 (gatairan, “to tear down, remove”), German zerren (“to tug”). Related to tear. Alternatively from a reduction of Old French martirier, from Late Latin *martyrāre.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

465	long	long, lengthy	adv,nadj	[lɔ͂]					461. long From Old French long, from longe, longue, feminine of lonc, lunc, from Latin longus, from Proto-Indo-European *dl̥h₁gʰós (“long”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
466	apprendre	to learn	v	[apʀɑ͂dʀ]		• Il a encore beaucoup à apprendre. He still has much to learn. • Je veux vous apprendre quelque chose. I want to teach you something. • Elle nous apprend le français. She is teaching us French. • Apprends ces noms par cœur. Learn these names by heart.	Il a encore beaucoup à apprendre. 506	le médecin, la médecin	physician, doctor	nm	[medsɛ͂]		• Je suis médecin. I'm a doctor. • Tu devrais voir le médecin. You should see the doctor. • Je veux un médecin. 507	la balle	ball, bullet	nf	[bal]					502. balle 1 From Middle French balle from Northern Italian balla (“ball”), from Lombardic *palla, *balla (“ball”), from Proto-Germanic *ballô (“ball”), from Proto-Indo-European *bholn- (“bubble”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰel- (“to blow, swell, inflate”). Akin to Old High German ballo, bal (“ball”) (German Ballen (“bale”); Ball (“ball”)). More at ball. From Middle French balle (“large bundle, package”), from Old French bale (“rolled-up bundle, packet of goods”), from Frankish *balla, from Proto-Germanic *ballô (“ball”), from Proto-Indo-European *bholn- (“bubble”), from Proto-Indo-European *bhel- (“to swell, inflate, blow”). 533	la montre	watch	nf	[mɔ͂tʀ]		• Tu as une montre. You have a watch. • Cette montre est très jolie. That watch is very nice. • Quel est le prix de cette montre? What is the price of this watch ? Quel est le prix de cette montre?		528. montre Deverbal from montrer (“show”); the meaning 'watch' is a specialisation of the older meaning 'something shown; something which shows'.	[1]	[2]	[3]
534	le pied	foot	nm	[pje]		• Ils vont au travail à pied. They go to work on foot. • Une table a quatre pieds. A table has four legs.	Ils vont au travail à pied. Une table a quatre pieds.		529. pied From Middle French pied, from Old French pié, from Latin pedem, accusative of pes. The <-d> is a later orthographical addition based on etymology. Ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *pṓds. Compare Catalan peu, Italian piede, Latvian pēda, Lithuanian pėda, Portuguese pé, Sardinian pei, Spanish pie.	[1]	[2]	[3]
535	le présent	present; gift	nadj	[pʀezɑ͂]		• Je serai présent. I'll be present. • Tous les membres étaient présents. All the members were present. • Beaucoup d'étudiants furent présents au cours. Many students were present at the lecture. • Tous les élèves sont présents. All the students are present. • Ils ne sont pas tous présents. All of them are not present.	Je serai présent. Tous les membres étaient présents. Beaucoup d'étudiants furent présents au cours. Tous les élèves sont présents. Ils ne sont pas tous présents.		530. présent Borrowed from Latin praesēns.	[1]	[2]	[3]
536	plusieurs	several	det,adj,pro	[plyzjœʀ]					531. plusieurs From Old French plusors, from a Vulgar Latin *plūsiōres, alteration of Late Latin plūriōres (by influence from plūs), from Latin plūres.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
537	marcher	to walk	v	[maʀʃe]		• Je peux marcher. I can walk. • Ça marchera. It'll work. • Marchez lentement. Walk slowly. • Ne lis pas en marchant. Do not read while walking.	Je peux marcher. Ça marchera. Marchez lentement. Ne lis pas en marchant.		532. marcher From Middle French, from Old French marchier, from Frankish *markōn, from Proto-Germanic, from Proto-Indo-European *merg-, *marǵ- (“edge, boundary, border”). 538	la lumière	light	nf	[lymjɛʀ]		• Je peux voir la lumière. I can see the light. • La lumière est meilleure par ici. The light is better over here.	Je peux voir la lumière. La lumière est meilleure par ici.		533. lumière From Latin lūmināria (“light”), neuter plural of lūmināre (“star”) become feminine, ultimately from lūmen. Doublet of luminaire.	[1]	[2]	[3]
539	la réponse	the answer, the response	nf	[ʀepɔ͂s]		• Ta réponse est juste. Your answer is correct. • Je connais la réponse. I know the answer. • Votre réponse est juste. 545	joli	pretty, attractive	adj	[ʒɔli]		• Tu es jolie en noir. You look good in black. • Joli coup! Nice shot ! • Sa fille est très jolie. Her daughter is very pretty. • Elle a un joli visage. She has a pretty face. • Ils m'ont montré beaucoup de jolies photos. They showed me a lot of nice pictures.	Tu es jolie en noir. Joli coup! Sa fille est très jolie. Elle a un joli visage. Ils m'ont montré beaucoup de jolies photos.		540. joli From Middle French joly (“considerable, ingenious, agreeable, pretty”), from Old French joli, jolif (“pretty, smart, joyful, merry”), possibly from Old Norse jól (midwinter festival), from Proto-Germanic *jehwlą, *jeulō (“Yule, Yule month, December”) (more at yule); alternatively from Vulgar Latin *gaudivus (from Latin gaudeō, more at joy). 575	le but	goal, aim, objective, purpose	nm	[by(t)]		• Quel est son but? What is its purpose ?	Quel est son but?		570. but 1 From Middle French but (“mark, goal”), from Old French but (“aim, goal, end, target”), from Old French butte (“mound, knoll, target”), from Frankish *but (“stump, log”), or from Old Norse bútr (“log, stump, butt”); both from Proto-Germanic *butą (“end, piece”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰÀud- (“to beat, push”). The semantic development from 'mound' to 'target' is likely from martial training practice (see target). Cognate with Old English butt (“tree stump”). More at butt. From boire.	[1]	[2]	[3]

603	écouter	to listen to	v	[ekute]		• Arrêtez donc de parler et écoutez la musique. Do stop talking and listen to the music. • Tu vas écouter. You will listen. • Je pense que vous devriez écouter. I think you ought to listen. • Personne ne s'arrête pour l'écouter. No one stops to listen to him. • J'ai écouté son histoire. I listened to her story.	Arrêtez donc de parler et écoutez la musique. Tu vas écouter. Je pense que vous devriez écouter. Personne ne s'arrête pour l'écouter. J'ai écouté son histoire.		597. écouter From Middle French escouter, from Old French escouter, from Vulgar Latin *ascultāre, from Latin auscultāre, present active infinitive of auscultō (“I listen”). Compare Catalan escoltar, Portuguese escutar, Romanian asculta. Doublet of ausculter.	[1]	[2]	[3]
604	la cuisine	cooking, kitchen	nf	[kɥizin]		• Je veux une nouvelle cuisine. I want a new kitchen. • Elle est dans la cuisine. It is in the kitchen.	Je veux une nouvelle cuisine. Elle est dans la cuisine.		598. cuisine From Old French cuisine, from Vulgar Latin *cocīna, from Latin coquīna, whence also Catalan cuina, Galician cociña, Italian cucina, Portuguese cozinha, Spanish cocina, and ultimately English kitchen, Dutch keuken and German Küche.	[1]	[2]	[3]
605	la relation	relationship	nf	[ʀ(ə)lasjɔ͂]		• Je ne connais rien de leur relation. I don't know anything about their relationship.	Je ne connais rien de leur relation.		599. relation From Old French relacion, from Latin relātiō.	[1]	[2]	[3]
606	le dossier	file, record; case	nm	[dosje]					600. dossier From dos (“back(side)”) +‎ -ier.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
607	sentir	to feel, smell	v	[sɑ͂tiʀ]		• Je voulais te faire sentir comme chez toi. I wanted to make you feel at home. • Ça sent bon. That smells nice. • Sentez ceci. Smell this. • Les fleurs sentent tellement bon. The flowers smell so good. • Elle sent mauvais. She smells bad.	Je voulais te faire sentir comme chez toi. Ça sent bon. Sentez ceci. Les fleurs sentent tellement bon. Elle sent mauvais.		601. sentir From Latin sentīre, present active infinitive of sentiō.	[1]	[2]	[3]
608	le blanc	white	adj,nm	[blɑ͂]		• Le blanc te va bien. You look good in white. • Ce chien est blanc. This dog is white. • Le chien est blanc. The dog is white.	Le blanc te va bien. Ce chien est blanc. Le chien est blanc.		602. blanc From Middle French blanc, from Old French blanc, from Late Latin, Vulgar Latin *blancus, from Proto-Germanic *blankaz (“bright, shining, blinding, white”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰleyǵ- (“to shine”). Akin to Old High German blanch 'bright, white' (German blank 'polished, naked'), Old Norse blankr 'white' (Danish blank 'bright, shiny'), Dutch blank 'white, shining'. More at blink, blind.	[1]	[2]	[3]
609	la chanson	song	nf	[ʃɑ͂sɔ͂]		• Je travaille sur une nouvelle chanson. I'm working on a new song. • J'aime chanter des chansons. I like to sing songs. • Il me faut apprendre de nouvelles chansons. I've got to learn some new songs. • Je voulais juste écrire des chansons. I just wanted to write songs. • J'aime écrire des chansons en français. I like to write songs in French.	Je travaille sur une nouvelle chanson. J'aime chanter des chansons. Il me faut apprendre de nouvelles chansons. Je voulais juste écrire des chansons. J'aime écrire des chansons en français.		603. chanson From Middle French chanson, from Old French chançon, inherited from Latin cantiō, cantiōnem (“song, singing”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
610	la gueule	mouth, trap	nf	[gœl]		• Il a une grande gueule. He has a big mouth.	Il a une grande gueule.		604. gueule From Old French goule, gole, from Latin gula, from Proto-Indo-European *gʷel- (“throat”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
611	foutre	to f*ck, shove off	v,nm	[futʀ]					605. foutre From Old French [Term?], inherited from Latin futuere, present active infinitive of futuō, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *bʰew- (“to hit”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

613	déjeuner	lunch; to have lunch	nm,v	[deʒœne]		• Je vous dois un déjeuner. I owe you a lunch. • Le déjeuner sera bientôt prêt. Lunch will be ready soon. • Je dois faire à déjeuner. I've got to make lunch. • Il a un déjeuner. He has a lunch.	Je vous dois un déjeuner. Le déjeuner sera bientôt prêt. Je dois faire à déjeuner. Il a un déjeuner.		607. déjeuner 1 From dé- +‎ jeûner (“un fast (to break fast)”) or from a Vulgar Latin *disieiūnāre, *disjejūnāre, from Late Latin ieiūnāre, jejūnāre, present active infinitive of ieiūnō, jejūnō, from Latin ieiūnus, jejūnus. Compare Spanish desayunar, Occitan dejunar. Doublet of dîner. Nominalization of the above verb.	[1]	[2]	[3]
614	pourtant	yet, nonetheless, nevertheless	adv	[puʀtɑ͂]					608. pourtant Univerbation of pour (“for”) +‎ tant (“so much”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

617	ouvrir	to open	v	[uvʀiʀ]		• Ouvre les yeux. Open your eyes. • Je peux ouvrir les yeux maintenant? Can I open my eyes now ? • Ouvre la porte. Open the door. • Ouvrez grand la bouche. Open your mouth wide. • Hé, ouvrez la porte. Hey, open the door.	Ouvre les yeux. Je peux ouvrir les yeux maintenant? Ouvre la porte. Ouvrez grand la bouche. Hé, ouvrez la porte.		611. ouvrir From Middle French ouvrir, from Old French ovrir, obrir, from Vulgar Latin *operīre, alteration of Classical Latin aperīre, present active infinitive of aperiō (“I open”), perhaps under the influence of cooperīre (“to cover”) (whence couvrir).	[1]	[2]	[3]
618	la âme	soul	nf	[ɑm]					612. âme From Middle French ame, amme, from Old French ame, anme, anima, from Latin anima. Compare also Gothic 𐌰𐌷𐌼𐌰 (ahma, “spirit; soul”).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

621	chacun	each	pro	[ʃakœ͂, ʃakyn]		• Chacun pense la même chose. Everyone thinks the same thing. • Chacun de nous devrait faire de son mieux. Each one of us should do his best. • Chacun l'aime. Everyone loves him. • Chacun dans sa classe l'aime. Everyone in her class likes her. • Chacun connaît la loi. Everyone knows the law.	Chacun pense la même chose. Chacun de nous devrait faire de son mieux. Chacun l'aime. Chacun dans sa classe l'aime. Chacun connaît la loi.		615. chacun From Middle French chascun, from Old French chascun, from Vulgar Latin *cascunum, *casquunum, a conflation of quisque unum (“each one”) + *cata unum, a variant form showing a derivative of Ancient Greek κατά (katá) (this variant form survived into Old French as chaün). Compare Occitan cadun, chascun, Catalan cadascun, Italian ciascuno.	[1]	[2]	[3]

624	la compagnie	company	nf	[kɔ͂paɲi]					618. compagnie From Old French compaignie, from compain + -ie or alternatively from compagne, from Vulgar Latin *compania, from Late Latin compāniō. See also copain, compagnon.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
625	la clé	key	nf	[kle]		• La clé est sur la table. The key is on the table. • Je pensais vous avoir donné la clé hier. I thought I gave you the key yesterday. • Voici la clé de ta chambre. Here's the key to your room. • Les clés étaient dans mon sac. The keys were in my bag. • Elle cherche les clés de sa voiture. She is looking for her car keys.	La clé est sur la table. Je pensais vous avoir donné la clé hier. Voici la clé de ta chambre. Les clés étaient dans mon sac. Elle cherche les clés de sa voiture.		619. clé From Middle French clef, from Old French clef, from Latin clāvem, accusative singular clāvis, from Proto-Italic *klāwis, of ultimately Proto-Indo-European origin. 644	le soin	care	nm	[swɛ͂]		• Prends soin de toi. Take care of yourself. • Prends bien soin de toi. Take good care of yourself. • Prends soin de ta santé. 810	le copain	friend, buddy, mate	nm	[kɔpɛ͂, kɔpin]					801. copain From Old French compaing, compain, from Late Latin compāniō (nominative form) (compare also Italian compagno), from com- +‎ pānis (literally, with + bread), a word first attested in the Frankish Lex Salica as a translation of a Germanic word, probably Frankish *galaibo, *gahlaibo (“messmate”, literally “with-bread”), from *hlaib (“loaf, bread”). 815	choisir	to choose	v	[ʃwaziʀ]		• Je ne sais pas lequel choisir. I don't know which to choose. • Vous pouvez choisir le livre que vous aimez. You can pick out any book you like. • Choisis entre les deux. Choose between the two. • Il choisit pour elle trois belles roses. He chose three beautiful roses for her. • Choisis une personne. Choisis une personne.		806. choisir From Middle French choisir, from Old French choisir, coisir (“to differentiate, see distinctly”), from Frankish *kausijan (“to choose”), from Proto-Germanic *kausijaną, *kauzijaną, from Proto-Germanic *keusaną (“to choose, taste”), from Proto-Indo-European *ǵews- (“to choose, taste”). Cognate with Franco-Provençal chouêsir (“to choose”), Germanic cognates include Old Frisian kēra (“to elect”). Related also to Gothic 𐌺𐌹𐌿𐍃𐌰𐌽 (kiusan, “to choose, examine”), Old High German kiosan (“to choose”), Old English ċēosan (“to choose”), Old Norse kjósa (“to choose”). More at choose.	[1]	[2]	[3]

852	ancien	ancient; former	adj,nm	[ɑ͂sjɛ͂]		• Ce livre est très ancien. That book is very old. • Le musée présente une exposition d'armes anciennes. The museum has an exhibit of ancient weapons.	Ce livre est très ancien. Le musée présente une exposition d'armes anciennes.		843. ancien From Middle French ancien, from Old French ancien, from a Vulgar Latin root *anteanus or *antianu, from Latin ante. As the word does not completely conform to the expected phonetic evolution, it may have been semi-learned and used initially by clerics who were aware of the Vulgar Latin word (which does not appear until the (Old) French one does). See also the related Old and Middle French ains.	[1]	[2]	[3]

910	amuser	to amuse	v	[amyze]		• Tu m'amuses. You amuse me.	Tu m'amuses.		901. amuser From Middle French amuser (“to amuse, divert, babble”), from Old French amuser (“to stupefy, waste time, be lost in thought”), from a- + muser (“to stare stupidly at, gape, wander, waste time, loiter, think carefully about, attend to”), of uncertain and obscure origin. Cognate with Occitan musa (“idle waiting”), Italian musare (“to gape idly about”). Possibly from Old French *mus (“snout”) from Vulgar Latin *mūsa (“snout”) (compare Medieval Latin mūsum (“muzzle, snout”)), from Proto-Germanic *mū- (“muzzle, snout”), from Proto-Indo-European *mū- (“lips, muzzle”). Compare German Maul (“muzzle, snout”).	[1]	[2]	[3]

C'est encore frais dans ma mémoire. Cognate with Old High German frisc (“fresh, young, new”), Old English fersċ (“fresh, pure, sweet”). More at fresh. Oblique plural of Old French fret, frait, from Latin fractum.	[1]	[2]	[3]

960	couper	to cut	v	[kupe]		• Tu devrais aller te faire couper les cheveux. You should go and have your hair cut. • Coupez le fil rouge. Cut the red wire. • Coupez le gâteau avec ce couteau. Coupez le gâteau avec ce couteau.		951. couper From Old French coper, colper (“to cut off”), probably, derived from cop (“blow”), colp (modern coup), with its meaning coming from the idea of cutting off with a blow. It may correspond to a Vulgar Latin verb *colpāre, syncopated form of *colaphāre, from Latin colaphus (compare Old Spanish golpar, colpar, Old Portuguese golpar, golbar). Je veux un morceau de gâteau.		958. morceau From Old French morsel (whence also English morsel), from Medieval Latin morsellum (“a bit, a little piece”), diminutive of Latin morsum (“a bit”), neuter of morsus, past participle of mordeō, mordēre (“bite, nibble, gnaw”), from Proto-Indo-European *merə- (“to rub, wipe; to pack, rob”). 978	le cinéma	cinema	nm	[sinema]		• J'ai envie d'aller au cinéma. I'd like to go to the movies. • Elle va au cinéma une fois par semaine. She goes to the movies once a week. • Je suis allée au cinéma avec mon frère. I went to the movies with my brother. • Je vais au cinéma une fois par mois. I go to the movies once a month. • Je vais au cinéma toutes les semaines. I go to the movies every week.	J'ai envie d'aller au cinéma. Elle va au cinéma une fois par semaine. 979	le discours	speech, talk, discourse	nm(pl)	[diskuʀ]		• C'était un beau discours. That was a beautiful speech. • Son discours fut excellent. Her speech was excellent. • Elle avait peur de faire un discours. She was afraid to make a speech.	C'était un beau discours. Son discours fut excellent. Elle avait peur de faire un discours.		969. discours From Middle French discours, borrowed (with influence from cours) from Late Latin discursus (“the act of running about”) (from Latin discurrō (“run about”), from dis- (“apart”) + currō (“run”)). 1028	le jardin	garden	nm	[ʒaʀdɛ͂]		• Je suis dans le jardin. I am in the garden. • J'adore votre jardin. I love your garden. • Elles sont au jardin. They're in the garden. • Le jardin est en face de la maison. The garden is in front of the house. • Mon père est dans le jardin. My father is in the garden.	Je suis dans le jardin. J'adore votre jardin. Elles sont au jardin. Le jardin est en face de la maison. Mon père est dans le jardin.		1018. jardin From Middle French jardin, from Old French jardin, ('garden, enclosure', probably from Vulgar Latin or early Gallo-Romance hortus gardinus, from Old Frankish *gardin, oblique case of *gardō (“enclosure, yard”) (compare also Old French jart (“garden”))), from Proto-Germanic *gardô (“enclosure, garden, house”), from Proto-Indo-European *gʰordʰos (“hedge, enclosure”), from Proto-Indo-European *gʰerdʰ- (“court, yard”). Cognate with Old High German gart, garto (“garden, enclosure, yard”), Old English ġeard (“garden, yard, fence, enclosure”). Cognate with English garden, which was derived from an Anglo-Norman/Old Northern French variant. More at yard.	[1]	[2]	[3]

1041	le génie	genius	nm	[ʒeni]		• C'est un génie. He is a genius. • Vous êtes un génie. You are a genius. • Ton fils est un génie. Your son is a genius. • Son fils est un génie. Il pense être un génie.		1031. génie Borrowed from Latin genius.	[1]	[2]	[3]
1042	inquiéter	to worry, disturb	v	[ɛ͂kjete]					1032. inquiéter Borrowed from Latin inquieto, inquietare.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

1046	le membre	member	nm	[mɑ͂bʀ]		• Je suis toujours membre. I'm still a member. • Je suis membre. I'm a member. • Je suis membre de l'équipe. I'm a member of the team.	Je suis toujours membre. Je suis membre. Je suis membre de l'équipe.		1036. membre Borrowed from Latin membrum.	[1]	[2]	[3]
1047	le réel	real	nadj	[ʀeɛl]		• C'est un fait réel. That is an actual fact. • La menace est réelle. The threat is real.	C'est un fait réel. La menace est réelle.		1037. réel Borrowed from Late Latin reālis (“actual”), from Latin rēs.	[1]	[2]	[3]
1048	le poids	weight	nm(pl)	[pwɑ]		• Elle prend du poids. She is gaining weight. • Une livre est une unité de poids. A pound is a unit of weight. • Elle essaie de perdre du poids. She is trying to lose weight.	Elle prend du poids. Une livre est une unité de poids. Elle essaie de perdre du poids.		1038. poids From Middle French poix, from Old French pois, peis, from Vulgar Latin *pēsum, from Latin pēnsum. Spelling influenced by Latin pondus with the same meaning; both ultimately from the root of pendō (“to hang”). Doublet of pensum, which was borrowed.	[1]	[2]	[3]
1049	prévenir	to prevent, warn; to notify	v	[pʀev(ə)niʀ]		• Je dois les prévenir. I must warn them. • Qui peut le prévenir? Who can prevent it ?	Je dois les prévenir. Qui peut le prévenir?		1039. prévenir Borrowed from Latin praevenīre, present active infinitive of praeveniō (“anticipate”).	[1]	[2]	[3]
1051	la poche	pocket	nf	[pɔʃ]		• Vide tes poches! Empty your pockets !	Vide tes poches!		1040. poche From Middle French, from Old French puche (“purse, small bag”), from Frankish *pokka, *pukka (“pouch, bag”), from Proto-Germanic *puk-, *pūka- (“bag, pouch”), from Proto-Indo-European *buk-, *bu-, *beu- (“to blow, swell”). Reinforced by Old Norse puki, poki (“bag, pocket”), from Old Northern French. Cognate with Middle Dutch poke, Alemannic German Pfoch (“purse, bag”), Old English pocca, pohha (“poke, pouch, pocket, bag”), and English pocket; compare also pouch.	[1]	[2]	[3]

1054	fantastique	fantastic, terrific, great, weird, eerie	nadj(f)	[fɑ͂tastik]		• C'est un endroit fantastique. This is a fantastic place. • Tu étais fantastique. You were fantastic. • Votre maison est fantastique. Your house is fantastic.	C'est un endroit fantastique. Tu étais fantastique. 1055	le fantôme	ghost, phantom	nm	[fɑ͂tom]		• Je pensais avoir vu un fantôme. I thought I saw a ghost.	Je pensais avoir vu un fantôme.		1044. fantôme From Old French fantosme, from Latin phantasma, from Ancient Greek φάντασμα (phántasma); alternatively, according to the TLFi, it may have arrived in French through Gallic Vulgar Latin in what is now southern France, from an Ionian Greek dialect brought to Marseilles, presumably in a form *phantagma > *phantauma. The later spelling in Old French thus reflects the influence of the spelling of phantasma, the standard Latin form.	[1]	[2]	[3]
1056	la viande	meat	nf	[vjɑ͂d]		• La viande est dure. The meat is tough. • C'est une belle pièce de viande. This is a beautiful piece of meat.	La viande est dure. C'est une belle pièce de viande.		1045. viande From Old French viande, from Late Latin *vīvanda, alteration of Latin vīvenda, from the neuter plural form of vīvendus, from vīvere (“to live”). 1058	le page, la page	page	nm,nf	[paʒ]		• Tourne la page. Turn the page. • Il me reste trois pages à lire. I have three more pages to go.	Tourne la page. Il me reste trois pages à lire.		1047. page 1 From Old French page, a borrowing from Latin pāgina (“page, strip of papyrus fastened to others”). From Old French page, possibly via Italian paggio, from Late Latin pagius (“servant”), probably from Ancient Greek παιδίον (paidíon, “boy, lad”), from παῖς (paîs, “child”); some sources consider this unlikely and suggest instead Latin pagus (“countryside”), in sense of 'boy from the rural regions'.	[1]	[2]	[3]

1094	le mensonge	the lie	nm	[mɑ͂sɔ͂ʒ]		• C'était un mensonge. That was a lie. • C'était un mensonge, bien sûr. It was a lie, of course. • Elle doit avoir dit un mensonge. Je suis fatigué de tous leurs mensonges.		1083. mensonge From Middle French mensonge, from Old French mençonge, mençunge, probably from a Vulgar Latin *mentionica, from Late Latin mentiō, mentiōnem (in the sense of 'lie' rather than 'mention'), probably formed from haplology of a root *mentītiō, from Latin mentītus, past participle of mentior. Où est mon pantalon?		1087. pantalon From Italian Pantalone; a character from the commedia dell'arte whose hose were portrayed as being down around his feet. 1111	signer	to sign	v	[siɲe]		• Veuillez signer ici. Please sign here. • Signez sur cette ligne. Sign on this line. • Signez juste ici. Just sign here. • Signez ceci. Sign this. • Signez ici. 1134	un aveugle, une aveugle	blind	nadj(f)	[avœgl]					1123. aveugle From Middle French aveugle < Old French avogle, from Late Latin *ab oculis (“without eyes”), possibly a calque of Greek ex ops or from a Latin construction viduus or vacuus ab oculis. Less likely from a Latin *alboculus, from albus + oculus. The current French form is either an exception to the normal sound shift from Latin '-cl-' or a semi-learned term; cf. the dialectal and popular aveuil (older aveule, avule). See also œil.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

1182	la chaise	chair	nf	[ʃɛz]		• Il est sous la chaise. It is under the chair. • J'adore cette chaise. I love that chair. • La chaise est près de la porte. The chair is close to the door. • La chaise est loin de la porte. The chair is far from the door. • J'aime ces chaises. I like these chairs.	Il est sous la chaise. J'adore cette chaise. La chaise est près de la porte. La chaise est loin de la porte. J'aime ces chaises.		1171. chaise Originally, simply a variant of chaire. From Middle French chaire, inherited from Latin cathedra (“seat”), a borrowing from Ancient Greek καθέδρα (kathédra). Doublet of chaire and cathèdre.	[1]	[2]	[3]

Compare Aragonese laco, Catalan llac, Esperanto lago, Italian lago, Maltese lag, Portuguese lago, Romanian lac, Sardinian lagu, Spanish lago.	[1]	[2]	[3]

It appears that she might change her mind. • Vous avez droit à votre opinion. You are entitled to your opinion. • J'avais peur de l'opinion des gens. I was afraid of what people would think. • Je veux ton opinion. I want your opinion.	J'ai une opinion différente. Il semble possible qu'elle change d'opinion. Vous avez droit à votre opinion. J'avais peur de l'opinion des gens. Je veux ton opinion.		1340. opinion From Middle French opinion, from Latin opīniō.	[1]	[2]	[3]
1354	le crème, la crème	cream	adji,nf	[kʀɛm]					1341. crème From Old French cresme, from Late Latin crama, Transalpine Gaulish word influenced by Latin chrisma (modern French chrême, from Ancient Greek χρῖσμα (khrîsma).	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

1379	la foule	crowd	nf	[ful]					1366. foule 1 From Middle French foule (“group of men, people collectively”), alteration (due to Middle French foule (“act of treading”)) of Old French foulc (“people, multitude, crowd, troop”), from Vulgar Latin, from Frankish *folc, *fulc (“crowd, multitude, people”), from Proto-Germanic *fulką (“collection or class of people, multitude; host of warriors”), perhaps from Proto-Indo-European *pleh₁- (“to fill”). Cognate with Old High German folc (“people collectively, nation”), Old English folc (“common people, troop, multitude”). More at folk. From Middle French foule (“the act of milling clothes or hats”) and fouler (“to trample, mill, fordo, mistreat”), from Old French foler (“to crush, act wickedly”), from Latin fullō (“I trample, I full”). More at full.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

1415	brûler	to burn	v	[bʀyle]		• Ça va brûler. It will burn.	Ça va brûler.		1401. brûler From Middle French brusler “to burn” from Old French brusler, bruller (“to burn”), a conflation of bruir (“to burn”) (from Frankish *brōjan (“to burn, scald”), from Proto-Germanic *brōaną “to scald”, from Proto-Indo-European *bʰerw-, *bhrew- “to boil, seethe”), and usler (“to scorch”), from Latin ustulāre (“to scorch”). Compare also Italian bruciare, from a Vulgar Latin form *brusiāre, which is probably related, as well as brustolare. The initial -br- has had other origins proposed, such as from a Gaulish source, or from a corruption of a form *combustulāre, from a change of prefix of ambustulāre, influenced by combustus. Akin to German brühen (“to scald”), Dutch broeien (“to heat”). More at broil, brew.	[1]	[2]	[3]

1437	installer	to install	v	[ɛ͂stale]					1423. installer From Middle French, from Medieval Latin installō (“to install, put in place, establish”), from in- + stallum (“stall”), from Frankish *stall (“stall, position, place”), from Proto-Germanic *stallaz (“place, position”), from Proto-Indo-European *stelǝ-, *stAlǝn-, *stAlǝm- (“stem, trunk”). Cognate with Old High German stal (“location, stall”), Old English steall (“position, stall”), Old English onstellan (“to institute, create, originate, establish, give the example of”), Middle High German anstalt (“institute”), German anstellen (“to conduct, employ”), German einstellen (“to set, adjust, position”), Dutch aanstellen (“to appoint, commission, institute”), Dutch instellen (“to set up, establish”). More at on, stall.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

1503	le roman	novel	adj,nm	[ʀɔmɑ͂]		• J'aime son roman. I like her novel. • Ce roman m'ennuie. This novel bores me. • Il a commencé à écrire un roman. 1540	un essai	attempt, try, test	nm	[esɛ]		• J'en ferai l'essai. I'll give it a try. • J'ai dû en faire un essai. I had to give it a try.	J'en ferai l'essai. J'ai dû en faire un essai.		1526. essai From Middle French, from Old French essai, from Late Latin exagium (“weighing”), hence English assay (compare also Spanish ensayo), from Latin exigō; the original sense of 'trial' (if the gold is good) drifted towards a general meaning of 'attempt'. The literary meaning is given by Michel de Montaigne's masterpiece.	[1]	[2]	[3]

Je le sais suffisamment bien. Tu es suffisamment vieux pour savoir ça.		1589. suffisamment From suffisant +‎ -ment. Pronunciation IPA(key): /sy.fi.za.mɑ̃/ Adverb suffisamment	[1]	[2]	[3]

1606	la télévision	television	nf	[televizjɔ͂]					1591. télévision From télé- (“far off”) +‎ vision (“seeing”), first used by Constantin Perskyi in a paper ('Télévision au moyen de l’électricité') read to the International Electricity Congress at the International World Fair in Paris on August 25, 1900. 1616	le sable	sand	adji,nm	[sɑbl]		• Le sable était chaud. The sand was warm.	Le sable était chaud.		1601. sable 1 From Old French, from Vulgar Latin or Late Latin sablum, from Latin sabulum, alternative form of sabulō. Compare sablon, which was used more often in Old French. Compare Italian sabbia, Occitan sabla. From Old French martre sable (“sable marten”), an animal. From Middle Low German sabel (compare Middle Dutch sabel, Middle High German zobel); ultimately from a Balto-Slavic word (compare Russian со́боль (sóbolʹ), Polish soból, Czech sobol). Compare also Persian سمور‎ (samur). From sabler	[1]	[2]	[3]

1654	un allemand	German	nadj	[almɑ͂]		• Je veux étudier l'allemand. I want to study German. • L'allemand est la meilleure langue du monde. German is the best language in the world. • Je parle un peu allemand. I speak a little German.	Je veux étudier l'allemand. L'allemand est la meilleure langue du monde. Je parle un peu allemand.		1639. allemand From Late Latin Alamannus or Alemannus (related to Alamans, ancient Germanic people for whom the name meant 'all men', 'all people', according to Asinius Quadratus). aleman became alemant by the addition of a terminal T of the singular objective case for adjectives of second class in Old French, and then alemand. The Latin word itself derives from the Old High German Alaman, from a Proto-Germanic *Alamanniz, likely from the roots *allaz (whence English all) and *manniz < *mann- (whence English man).	[1]	[2]	[3]

Je suis en congé cette semaine.		1640. congé From Old French congié, cungié, cunged, congiet, cumgiet, from Latin commeātus. As an architectural term, a Calque of Ancient Greek ἀποφυγή (apophugḗ, “a leave, an escape; an architectural feature”).	[1]	[2]	[3]

1708	la race	breed, race	nf	[ʀas]					1693. race From Italian razza, from Old High German reiza (“line”), or possibly from Arabic رَأْس‎ (raʾs, “head”). Alternatively, razza may have been borrowed from Old French haraz (“culture of horses”) as well. Another theory is that the Italian word came from Latin ratiō (the nominative, as opposed to ragione from the accusative ratiōnem, which nonetheless was attested with a similar sense to razza in the late Middle Ages; ratio also came to mean 'idea' or 'conception of something' in Ecclesiastical Latin), and underwent a change of gender later from an original form *razzo, or else derived ultimately from generātiō through apheresis.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

1731	la panne	the breakdown, the failure (of a machine)	nf	[pan]		• J'avais une panne. I had a breakdown.	J'avais une panne.		1716. panne From Old French panne (“a fur lining; a warp resulting from such a lining, hence a breakdown”) from Medieval Latin panna, alteration of Latin penna (“quill”) from pinna (“feather, wing”). The transition of sense from 'feather/wing' to 'fur' is due to an associative analogy to the corresponding Frankish word *feder, which could mean both 'feather' and 'fur'; compare Old High German vëder, federe (“feather'/'fur”). Il me faut maintenant m'habiller.		1782. habiller From Old French abiller, from a- +‎ bille + -er. 1822	rêver	to dream	v	[ʀeve, ʀɛve]		• J'ai dû rêver. I must've been dreaming. • Nous pouvons toutes rêver. We can all dream.	J'ai dû rêver. Nous pouvons toutes rêver.		1806. rêver From Middle French resver, from Old French resver (“to consider, reflect, be delirious”), of uncertain origin. The Trésor de la langue française informatisé links it back either to an unattested *esver (“to wander”) or to Latin *reexvadō, from re- +‎ ex- +‎ evadō[1]. The Französisches Etymologisches Wörterbuch links it back to *reexvagus, hence the same as the first proposal by the Trésor de la langue française informatisé[2].	[1]	[2]	[3]
1823	le vague, la vague	vague; wave	nadj(f),nf	[vag]		• J'ai un vague souvenir. I have a vague recollection.	J'ai un vague souvenir.		1807. vague 1 From Middle French, from Old French vague (“movement on the surface of a liquid, ripple”), from Old Norse vágr (“sea”), from Proto-Germanic *wēgaz (“wave, storm”), from Proto-Indo-European *weǵhe- (“to drag, carry”). Cognate with Swedish våg (“wave”), Middle Dutch waeghe, wage (“wave”), Old High German wāge (“wave”), Old English wǣg (“wave, billow, motion, flood”). More at waw, wave. From Middle French vague, from Latin vagus (“wandering, rambling, strolling, fig. uncertain, vague”).	[1]	[2]	[3]

1942	le câble	cable, wire	nm	[kɑbl]					1926. câble From cable, an Old Northern French (i.e. Old Norman or Picard) variant of chable, cheable, chaable, from Vulgar Latin *caplum, contracted form of Late Latin capulum, from Latin capiō. The Norman-Picard form, used primarily in a maritime sense, coexisted with the Francien dialect forms until replacing them by the 18th century. The Old French forms cheable and chaable were crossed with or influenced by the separate word chaable (“catapult”), from a Vulgar Latin *cadabulum.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

Nous avons un bon groupe de volontaires.		1960. volontaire From Middle French voluntaire, from late Old French voluntaire, borrowed from Latin voluntārius (“voluntary; volunteer”), from voluntās (“free will”), from volō, velle (“wish, intend”). Compare volontiers, inherited from a related word.	[1]	[2]	[3]

Prenez ce médicament avant chaque repas.		2069. médicament Borrowed from Latin medicamentum.	[1]	[2]	[3]

2124	piquer	to sting, bite, prick, be hot; to steal	v	[pike]					2108. piquer From Middle French picquer, from Old French piquer (“to pierce with the tip of a sword”) (cf. also pikier), from proto-Romance or Vulgar Latin *pīccare (“to sting, strike”) or *pikkāre (compare Occitan, Catalan, Portuguese, and Spanish picar), itself either from an onomatopoetic root *pikk- (cf. also Latin picus, whence French pic), or alternatively, from Frankish *pikkōn, from Proto-Germanic *pikōną, *pukaną (“to pick, peck, prick, knock”), from Proto-Indo-European *beu-, *bu- (“to make a dull sound”). Cognate with Old English pȳcan, pician (“to pick, pluck”), Old Norse pikka (“to prick, peck”), Middle Dutch and Middle Low German picken (“to pick, peck, pierce”), Middle High German puchen (“to knock, defy, plunder”). 2183	un ingénieur, une ingénieur	engineer	nm,nf	[ɛ͂ʒenjœʀ]		• Je suis ingénieur. I'm an engineer.	Je suis ingénieur.		2167. ingénieur Modified, based on the verb ingénier, from Old French engigneor, itself from engin or from Medieval Latin ingeniator or ingeniārius (“one who makes or uses an engine”), from Latin ingenium (“an engine”), from in (“in”) + gignō, gignere (“to produce, cause”). The distinction was likely intentionally made to separate the word from the unrelated Old French engigneor (“deceiever”).	[1]	[2]	[3]

2282	la tache	stain, spot, mark	nf	[taʃ]		• Cette tache refuse de partir. This stain won't come out.	Cette tache refuse de partir.		2266. tache From Middle French, from Old French tache, taiche, taje (“mark, spot, stain”), from Vulgar Latin *tacca, *tecca, from Gothic 𐍄𐌰𐌹𐌺𐌽𐍃 (taikns, “mark, sign”), from Proto-Germanic *taiknaz, *taikną (“sign, mark”), from Proto-Indo-European *deik'e-, *deig'- (“to show”). Influenced by forms related to Frankish *stakjan, *stakkjan (“to stick, attach”) and Gothic 𐍃𐍄𐌰𐌺𐍃 (staks, “mark”). See attacher. For levelling and shortening of diphthong ai in taikns compare Old French hanter, hangart, etc. Cognate with Old High German zeihhan (“sign, symbol, feature”), Old English tācn (“sign, marker”). More at token.	[1]	[2]	[3]

2396	noyer	walnut; to drown, flood, blur, water down	nm,v	[nwaje]		• Elle a failli se noyer. She came close to drowning.	Elle a failli se noyer.		2380. noyer 1 From Vulgar Latin nucārius (“nut tree”) from Classical Latin nux. Compare Spanish noguera, Portuguese nogueira, Catalan noguera, Occitan noguièr. Equivalent to noix +‎ -ier. From Old French noier, from Latin necāre, present active infinitive of necō (“kill”). The sense of 'to drown' can be found in other Romance cognates; compare Italian annegare, Spanish anegar, Romanian îneca.	[1]	[2]	[3]

2517	le compagnon	companion, craftsman, journeyman	nm	[kɔ͂paɲɔ͂]					2501. compagnon From Old French compaignon, from Late Latin compāniō (literally “he with whom one shares one's bread”) (compare Italian compagnone, Spanish compañón), from com- (“with”) + pānis (“bread”), first attested in the Frankish Lex Salica as a calque of a Germanic word represented by Gothic 𐌲𐌰𐌷𐌻𐌰𐌹𐌱𐌰 (gahlaiba, “messmate”) from 𐌲𐌰- (ga-, “with”) + 𐌷𐌻𐌰𐌹𐌱𐌰 (hlaiba, “bread”), Old High German galeipo, itself from Proto-Germanic *ga- (“togetherness”) + *hlaibaz (“loaf, bread”). Compare with the etymologically related terms copain and compagnie. More at co-, loaf.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

Akin to Old English latian (“to delay, hesitate”), Old English lǣfan (“to leave”). More at delay.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

3102	le cliché	cliché; negative	nm	[kliʃe]					3086. cliché Past participle of clicher (“to stereotype, (originally) to copy”, literally “to click, clink”), from Middle French clicher, from Old French cliquer (“to click, clack, sound, resound”), of Germanic origin, related to Dutch klikken (“to click, rattle”), Low German klikken (“to click”), German klicken (“to click”), Danish klikke (“to click”), Swedish klicka (“to click”). 3592	le flot	floodtide, stream of, flood of	nm	[flo]					3576. flot From Middle French flot (“considerable quantity of poured liquid, stream, flow”), from Old French flot (“mass of moving water, flood, tidal flow”), partly from Old Norse flóð (“stream, river, flood, massive flow of water”); partly from Frankish *flota (“flux, streaming flow”); and partly from Frankish *flōd (“river, flood”); all from Proto-Germanic *flōduz (“river”), Proto-Germanic *flutōną (“flow”), from Proto-Indo-European *plōw- (“to pour, wash”). Cognate with Old Dutch fluod (“river”), Old High German fluot (“flood”), Old English flōd (“river, flood”), Gothic 𐍆𐌻𐍉𐌳𐌿𐍃 (flōdus, “river, stream”). More at fleuve, flood, flow.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]

3691	la douane	customs, duty	nf	[dwan]					3674. douane Attested in 1281 in the form dohanne with the meaning 'building where the rights of entry and exit of goods are earned' (Angevin Archives of Naples). In 1441 in the form doana (“rights of entry and exit of goods”). Borrowed from Sicilian Medieval Latin doana, dovana (attested from the end of the 12th century), whence the modern Italian dogana, borrowed from the vernacular Arabic *دُوَان‎ (*duwān), an alteration of the Arabic دِيوَان‎ (dīwān), borrowed from Persian دیوان‎ (dīwān, “customs, divan”). Cognate with Old High German weidanōn (“to hunt, chase”), German Weide (“pasture, pasturage”). 4139	étonner	to astonish, amaze	v	[etɔne]					4122. étonner From Middle French estonner, from Old French estoner (“to be dizzy due to a violent blow”), of obscure origin. Possibly from Old Frankish *stunōn (“to make a loud sound”), from Proto-Germanic *stunōną (“to make a sound, groan”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)ten- (“to thunder, rustle, drone, groan”). Cognate with Old English stunian (“to crash, make a loud sound”) (see stun); or from a hypothetical Latin *extonare (“to thunder out”) from ex (“out”) + tonare (“to thunder”), ultimately from the same Proto-Indo-European root; or a fusion of both.	[ ]	[ ]	[3]
